text: Smoked stout from Dark Horse, older bottle from Biergenot but I cannot be bothered by its age as heavy stouts / porters in general and smoked ones in particular tend to keep very well... Irregular, deep brownish beige, moussy head lacing in dots, dissolving almost instantly in the middle but retaining well around the edges with some thin patches of greyish foam in the middle, atop a black beer with hazy chestnut brown edges. Aroma is indeed smoky but quite roasted as well, with hints of charcoal (not much smoked bacon though), a lot of caramel, fondant chocolate, cold black coffee and even coffee liqueur, dried sage, bayleaf, leather, burnt toast, pralines, candied fig, kahlua, burnt barbecued meat without the meat, Cuban cigars, hazelnut oil, liquorish, salmiak, roasted peanuts, butterscotch, iron-like clotted blood, hint of black cherry juice and only the faintest hint of - in this case - very elegant, very old madera-like oxidation. Dried fruits in the onset, some very subdued fig and raisin sweetishness with a dimly sourish edge and light umami accents of roast beef and - far away - dried porcini, altogether very clean and to the point, softly carbonated with a slick, smooth, oily mouthfeel, with something very vaguely metallic on its edges. The sourish roasted barley persists through a middle phase of nutty and very toasted black maltiness which gains a coffeeish roasted bitter character before the finish, with those dried fruit aspects on top; ends bitter and a tad ashy with that smoked bacon-like factor woven into it, but nothing is overdone here, this beer keeps itself together perfectly till the last drop. I get a very, very faint hint of retronasal oxidation, in this case only adding some complexity; finishes with ongoing roasted and mildly smoked maltiness, peppery hop bitterness and a faint afterglow of warming, gin-like alcohol which does not otherwise interfere with any of the aforementioned flavours. Roasted, coffeeish but also more gentle, lovely bitter chocolate bitterness is the lasting impression after swallowing, as the smoke thing has already faded at that point. Very nice, gracious example of a smoked stout; ever since Alaskan started its famed Smoked Porter, it is usually porters who get the smoky treatment, but this surely qualifies as a stout, with the black roasted bitterness remaining the prime factor in the overall profile of the beer and the smokiness having been added as an extra touch, presenting itself stronger in the nose and retronasally than in the actual flavour, though the Rauchbier association is always there from the first sip to the last. Not too complex but technically very well done, going straight to its own goal without further ado, in an elegant, clean and very well-balanced manner. Very nice beer in its specific context and its age - Im roughly guessing a few years - has indeed been of practically no influence, apart from this very slight background hint of maderisation, which only made this more beautiful. Highly recommended to those who are into smoked porters, even though this is indeed a stout in its general make-up.

So many porters include smoke, but I havent seen too many stouts. This isnt bad. Pours a deep, dark black, with an almost purpleish head. Aroma of smoke, roasted grain, chocolate, coffee. Flavor is also mainly smoke (almost tastes like smoked meat), along with some sweetness, chocolate, licorice, coffee. etc.

Opaque, black. 
Medium body, moderate flavor, thin texture, crisp, rich and moderately hot mouthfeel, short length. 
Restrained bittersweet nature, fitting acidity. 
Predominantly roast flavors, coffee, bitter chocolate, 
Quite pleasant.

At a tasting, thanks, very little head, opaque black color, aroma of chocolate cake, wood and dark bread in the back, flavor of dark chocolate, coal and dark bread in the back, pleasant light bitterness. Nice though not really smokey.

In overall once again above average stout from Dark Horse, this time with hints of some smoked notes.

Chocolate and typical stout taste. Not much smoke though. 
Ok but not more

Bottle, 0.355l. Pours pitch black wit thin creamy brown head and sparkling appearance. Aroma of roasted malt, smoke, leather, meat and licorice. Taste starts with rich roasted and smoked malt, follows by sweet chocolate, mild licorice and light alcohol note mouthfeel is warming and spicy, while finish is mild bitter. Aroma contains moderate malts (dark bread, roasted and burnt malts, molasses, milk chocolate, mild coffee), moderate hops (herbs, spruce, orange, lemon), light yeasts (leather, cheese, earth) and banana, grape, raisin, plum, cassis, smoke, brown sugar, vanilla, cola, licorice, forest fruits and spices.

Body is full with syrupy texture and soft carbonation.
Very subtle and complex, roasted malts and smoke gently in the background. Hoppy fruits are up front, but not overwhelming. Fantastic mouthfeel.

Kolor: Czarny, nieprzejrzysty, piwo jest klarowne.
Piana:Średnio obfita, drobnopęcherzykowa, mało trwała. Lacing śladowy.
Aromat: Czekolada, odrobina spalonych kabli. Poza tym dosyć mocne żelazo, które powinno mi przeszkadzać, ale ku mojemu zdumieniu całkiem przyjemnie komponuje się z resztą aromatów. Nieźle. Przy wąchaniu retronosowym wychodzi więcej tej torfowej wędzonki (spalonych kabli).
Smak: Piwo jest półwytrawne, średnio pełne. Goryczka niska (mogłaby być wyższa), kakaowa, przyjemna. W smaku w mniej więcej równych proporcjach miesza się czekolada i wędzonka torfowa. Z tyłu plącze się odrobina kawy. Żelazo jest mniej wyczuwalne niż w aromacie.
Wysycenie: Niskie - idealne.
Opakowanie: Fajny rysunek i absolutny brak informacji. Mogłoby być dużo lepiej.
Uwagi: Nie jestem fanem wędzonki torfowej, ale tu jest ona okiełznana i całkiem przyjemna. Niezły stout wędzony. Żelazistość do poprawy.

Pitch black with a small brown head. Taking the color of it Im surprised by a subtil and moderate roastiness to it. I get some peated, fruity and coca-cola like aromas. Interesting. The beer is medium oily and has a delicate carbonation. Flavor is medium sweet, a bit dry and has a roasty aftertaste but not overwhelming. Good balance and hides well the alcohol. An easy drinker.

Some sweetness, especially on the finish. Bitterness, but seems more from the deep roasted and smoke flavors than from the hops(?).

Overall a pretty good smoked stout. I like the degree of smokiness and the long and varied finish. The base stout is not a great one which holds down the rating a bit.

The palate is surprisingly light bodied and foamy. The palate shows dominant roasted malts with very faint hints of chocolate. The finish shows a long bitter smokiness. The bitterness comes off a little strong and doesnt really display the coffee/espresso type bitterness.

Bottled December 23rd. Poured into a Sam Adams Perfect Pint on March 24th. $2.19 single.

Appearance: Pitch black with a fizzy dark brown head that goes away quickly. No lacing. Pretty average.

Smell: Roasty and smokey with an almost caramel popcorn aroma. I really like it. Not as smokey as some other stouts Ive had, but its there nicely.

Taste/feel: Hm. Alright. Well, I can say that its quite bitter, but not a good bitter. A burnt sort of bitter. I cant really so much taste a burnt flavor, but the bitterness reminds me of... burnt. Not in a horrific, it-ruins-the-beer way, but I could do without it. The mouthfeel is more like a porter than a stout, as it feels relatively thin with a medium-to-high carbonation. The smoke flavor is in this beer like it is the aroma -- complimentary, but quite mild. In comparison, the smoke in this beer is a decent bit less significant than the blueberry was in Dark Horses Tres Blueberry Stout. Theres no "meatiness" that I love in a good smoked porter or stout, just a smoke and coffee flavor that combines to give an ashy vibe. As it warms, that "burnt bitterness" I was talking about goes in the backseat, and a sweetness comes through without accompanied flavors (dark fruits or whatever else).

All-in-all, my least favorite of One, Too, Tres, Fore, and Plead the Fifth if that counts. This would be a good one for people who like stouts, but not so much smokey ones. The smoke is in this beer, but not in a huge way like I guess I was hoping.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, late 2012 bottling.  Pours dense pitch black color with a small fairly dense dark tan head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, char, roasted malt, coffee, smoke, light smoked meat, light wood, toast, and roasted earthiness. Damn nice flavor balance and robustness of dark roasted flavors with smoke; and zero cloying sweetness present after the finish. Originally reviewed: 11/4/10. 12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a very thick gluggy black, like used motor oil. A thin mocha head rest atop. Retention was weak; no lace. But this black abyss is haunting. I like it. The nose doesnt yield much smoke. Maybe some hints of charred wood, but it smells of a standard stout. Scents of chocolate, dark malt, faint coffee. A little disappointed theres not more smoke in the nose.

The body is thick and creamy. Perfect for a stout. An easy drinker though. Nothing too filling, but it just coats the palate wonderfully. The flavor doesnt hint that there is much smoke in this either. I guess I was expecting more of a Rauchbier-like smokiness, but this is subtle and definitely in the background. There are hints of the charred wood and burnt toast, but really, the chocolate/coffee combo is the main player. Lots of semi-sweetness, full bready toasted malts, and hints of dark fruits on the finish. As a "smoked" beer, this isnt what Id be looking for, but as an easily-drinkable tasty stout, this fit the bill perfectly. Loved it.

*Note: This is a winter release, so Im assuming this is an 09?? Maybe the smoke fades a bit after some time.

M.  Thick and heavy body, medium carbonation, very chewy.

O.  A good beer, not as smoky as I would expect from a beer called "smoked."  But still has solid bold flavor, with a hearty thick feel.  A filling beer.

Something must have gone wrong with the bottle I bought.  Ive never experienced this before and I had to step away and try it a second time, to double check before I passed judgment.  Unfortunately it still had the same 2 problems: (1) it smelled like human waste. (2) It tasted burnt, like ashes of a log, rather than the flavor that I usually really enjoy in smoked styles.
Bottle. A mix of stoutish roasted note and a smoked. Turns out to be neither, rather than both (to be harsh). Still not bad, though.

Bottle at Bishops Linnegatan.
A rather dull smoked stout, taste and aroma dominated of chcolate with just some smokyness.

Nose is earth, salami, cream, stale espresso, heavy roasted malt, sweet alcohol whiff, feel is initially thin, but broaden a bit, carb Is medium, taste is cork, stale, sweet espresso, weak cream, oak, weak, late Iron

This is 1 awesome beer  Black body with a fine, creamy brown head. Aroma is not to heavy smoke on a malt base. Flavor is mild roasted malt, smoke, balanced sweet, fruity and some chocolate sweetness with moderate and balanced bitterness. Long and pleasant smoky aftertaste. A nice one.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2016 Black/brown pour, a finger of brown head that quickly disapates into a thin ring that leaves traces of lacing all the way down.  Aroma of chocolate, smoke, coffee, roasted malts.  Very complex taste - dark Chocolate, smoke, coffee, roasted malt, roasted grain, worcestershire, dark fruit, toffee - the aroma does not reflect how good this stout tastes.  
lighter carbonation, creamy mouthfeel.  A stout I could drink throughout the winter.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2013 First rating12 fl oz bottle at Rotary Pub, on November 30, 2011Black color, big lasting dark brown head, looks very nice! Sweet, chocolate, charcoal, smoke, lactic, salty scent. Also a touch of alcohol. Malty, grainy, dry, acidic, bitter taste. Dry, roasted, coffee, grainy, bitter taste. Dry, roasted, coffee, grainy, butter aftertaste. The initial acidiness goes away, pretty much with the second sip. The prolonged dry mix of coffee and dry high cocoa content chocolate aftertaste is nice. Borders to an 8 in the taste, but something I cant put my finger on draws in down to a "7+". Smooth but also somewhat spritzy mouthfeel. Medium bitterness to the dry side.Ill probably drink it again it I get the chance.8/5/7/4/15=3.9RerateBottle at Gothenburg Beer Festival 2013 (Haket), Sunday, sampled on September 8, 2013.So tried it again, but didnt at all like it as much as the first time. Leaving the first score.Black color, small brown head. Sweet, alcohol, grainy scent. Grainy, malty, raosted taste. Medium to thin mouthfeel, medium high dry grainy bitterness.7/3/6/3/12=3.1

Bottle 33cl from Allen thanks very much. A very dark and dense beer with a brown head. Nose is sweet and creamy like with bitter chocolate and vanilla notes. Aroma is on creamy dark chocolate, caramel, biscuits, cereal, buckwheat, slightly smoked, sweet, lactose notes, nice texture. Finish is sweet and smooth, no acidity, long roasted aftertaste with tobacco and dark chocolate note. What a nice stout, so drinkable, I would like to brew as well as this.

Bottled at Bishop Arms Vasagatan, Stockholm.  Pitch black, brief dark born head. Intense chocolate aroma. Sweet with medium-full body and dense, well rounded mouthfeel. Milk chocolate and mild smoke. Flavourful, but not overpowering. Balanced bitterness. Nice!

355ml bottle from Bierkompass, no BBE found. Poured black with a brown thin head. Nice roasted aroma, oat and coffee as well. Not much smoke though. Flavor is roasted, coffee, some chocolate as well as oat. Long dry finish with chocolate notes. Smooth, oily palate. Excellent stout.
(Bottle 25/10-2011) Brown very low head, black color, smoked roasted aroma, dry smoked slightly bitter taste. Really good.
Black with a small dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate and moderate smoky - bacon. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. Smooth. 251011

I was really looking forward to this beer.  Overall, it was a good beer, not great, and not in the smoked category.  Aroma had a hint of smoked flavor, but definitely fell short in this category as taste.  Maybe hint of an imperial stout, but again, a good stout.  Medium body, chocolate coffee taste.

Well, I had this last night.  I went in blind on this one.  The first thing I can say is that, there was not a lot of smoke to be found.  Just a touch in the aroma.  But, mostly your standard stout characteristics.  Same goes for the flavor, and honestly I didnt get any smoke in the taste.  I will say that, I had no idea it was 8%.  I figured it was 6% or so.  Decent on the whole.

Bottle 33cl. Black beer with brown creamy and persistent head, good lacing. Licorice and roasted aroma. Smoked, toasted, roasted, licorice and wood taste. On palate results a beer with full body, medium bitterness, oily feel, flat carbonation. Dry and bittery finish. Another excellent beer rated.

pours a nice black with off white head. I got a lot more smoke in the nose than in the flavor. Tastes more like a standard stout to me. Dark malts, coffee, and chocolate are the dominant flavors in this brew. Very tasty none the less.

A nice beer, though I wouldnt label it as a smoked beer. There is some smokey flavor, but its more of an imperial stout. Aroma was decent. Dark chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. Pour was a nice near black with a few rising bubbles and a thin tan ring for a head. Taste was very bitter and coffee-like. Dark chocolate filled the mouth and cheeks. Bittered everything before the swallow. A slight smokiness rose up through the sinuses but it was very faint. The aftertaste was very dry, chocolately and bitter. Very little smoke flavor but a good beer nonetheless. Just a little too ordinary to be great
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottle, sample at GBF 2011 cons 2011-09-02
AR: smokey coffey, caramel
AP: dark brown, wee dark beige head
F: great choclate, ash, caramel

Bottle. Dark brown, short and fully diminishing dark brown head. Moderate, malty  faint oat and sweetish aroma, roasted malt, coffee, some licorice and faint smokiness. Body is medium, malty  some oat and sweetish flavor, roasted malt and coffee, faint licorice. Finish is average, malty  some oat and lightly sweetish, roasted malt and coffee, some hoppyness and licorice. Sweetish stout with more coffee and oat than smokiness.

(bottle) Pours black with a brown head. The aroma holds chocolate and smoke up front with undertones of dark grainy bread, mild tar and salt. Smooth, well balanced and fancy on the nose. Almost dusty roast wise. The flavour light sweet to dry, light bitter and tiny acidic. Tones of chocolate, dark bread, smoke, light tar and subtle hops. The mouthfeel is clean, soft, and slim with near medium carbonation. Maybe a bit too tart. Chocolaty and smokey finish. Medium bodied.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Near pitch black with thin brown head. No lacing.

Aroma: Molasses, licorice and chocolate. Fairly sweet and only the slightest hint of smoke.

Taste: Not as sweet as the aroma, with chocolate, coffee, molasses and licorice. Turns a little bitter at the finish with char and harsh roasted notes.

Palate: Moderate carbonation with a medium to full body. Quite dry but a little chalky and not as smooth as the best Stouts.

Overall: Very good Stout overall. The charred notes add a nice layer of complexity to what would have otherwise been a fairly straightforward Stout.

On draft. Appearance is a dark black with a creamy, beige head of foam that diminishes quickly. Aroma is a barbecue and bacon combination that is just barely hinting at a presence of chocolate. Taste is the barbecue and bacon immediately, chocolate comes through if you let the beer set on the tongue, and then as soon as you swallow, more bacon and barbecue come through. I do enjoy the smokiness of this one. Its not overpowering like some smoked beers tend to be, but rather a melding of flavors.

from Erzbierschof.ch - dark black beer with a fast vanishing head; fairly smokey aroma of dark chocolate, licorice and vanilla; low carbonation, some sweetness and a decent bitterness; medium-bodied; quite dry and long smokey chocolatey finish with more notes of vanilla

Bottle.
Pitch black, quite thick liquid with a creamy dark brown head.
Aroma: dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt.
Taste: dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans, some chili, not very smoky, actually pretty smooth and balanced.
Above medium-bodied, soft bubbles.

Another gem from Josh - thanks man!  Aggressive pour produces a large, frothy expresso-tinged head.  Aroma is heavily roasted, semi-dry malt with a pleasant, medium-light level of smoke.  Taste is heavy roasted malt, light chocolate, and pleasant, light smoke through the finish.  As it warms, I get a little bit of off-flavor dirty dish rag in the back half.  LIght feel in the mouth.  Good beer but I would consider this smoke-light as far as the style goes.  I much preferred Yazoo Sue over this beer.

12 ounce bottle from Julios.  Picked up a Fore-pack (Ha! Im so funny) for $8.99.  WTF?  If they can sell this for that cheap, then other people are ripping us off.  Black as Dick Cheneys soul with a flat head thats brown as the shitstains on his underwear.   Rich smokey ash earthy espresso chocolate aroma.  Smokey earthy chocolate coffee molasses with medium but not gross dark fruit and mouth-coating roasted coffee smokey ashy bittersweet finish. Very full bodied.  Excellent.  Love it.  Demonstrates the awesomeness of peat, which has taken a not necessarily deserved back seat to wood smoke.  Bravo.
On Tap at Darkhorse. Poured a deep black with chocolate head. Roasted coffee aroma with smoky bbq hints. Nice mouthy feel and roasted malt taste. A very nice stout indeed.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle a dark jet black with a tan head, aromas of chocolate, and smoked malt.  Flavors of choclate, toffee, and a decent smoke/bbq finish.

Extremely deep black with a huge cappuccino colored head. Roasted aroma with strong notes of coffee and brown sugar. There are some fruity elements there as well: plums and grapefruits. Taste is sweet and bitter with a slight tartness underneath. Its difficult to detect the smoke - maybe the beer is just heavily "packed" to have room for such refinements?

SCHIUMA:
color marrone intenso, fine, media presenza con un residuo resistente
COLORE:
color caffe, impenetrabile 
INTENSITA / FINEZZA / AROMA
profumo  intenso, con sfumature di caffe, cioccolato e affumicato, tutto ben orchestrato.  Una punta di alcohol misto ad un leggero tocco fruttato
GUSTO / RETROGUSTO / PERSISTENZA
entra abbastanza neutra,  lasciando spazio a malti tostati, un affumicato sornione però ben distinguibile, con  successivi toni di caffe e cioccolato nero. Un tocco acidulo che ricorda il fruttato accompagna verso il finale dove si enfatizza un buon amaro torrefatto e qualche luppolo però ben miscelato e non ben distinguibile. sul finale si sente qualcosina di alcol.
CORPO / CARBONATAZIONE / CONSISTENZA
corpo medio, bassa carbonatazione, morbida in bocca.
CONCLUSIONE
nonostante evidenti toni affumicati, direi che rientra  più propriamente in una stout ben strutturata. Cremosa in bocca, con i classici sapori tipici dello stile, tendente forse più ad una imperial stout anche se la componente alcolica rimane  nascosta e  non domina . sapori e profumi ben dosati nelle varie componenti per un prodotto equilibrato e piacevole. mi favorita rimane comunque la black (ale) riserva. Manca quel tocco di originalità.
Yet another solid stout from Dark horse. Good appearance, aroma, and body. Strong finish. You do actually pick up some smoky flavor in there. Good beer.

Pours a dark black color with milk chocolate colored head.  Aroma of chocolate, roast, and a hint of earthiness with perhaps a touch of citrus in there somewhere.  Sweet chocolate taste with a great roastiness and a hop hit.  Earthiness and chocolate linger through the finish.  Nice thick mouthfeel.  This brewery continues to impress with every brew sampled.
Bottled 355ml. Tallish very dark beige head. Strong smokiness throughout. Lovely tar components. Remarkably dry finish. Delicious.

Bottle from Bierkompass. Almost black color with medium beige head. Aroma of wood, chocolate, caramel, hints of dark fruit. Taste, red fruit, chocolate, coffee, caramel. Dry, bitter palate. Bitter finish with charcoal notes. Good.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown excellent fully lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Peated malt slightly present. powerfull moderate bitter flavor. Long moderate bitter finish. Chocolate, coffee and slight ly smoked. Wonderfull.

Black pour. Small tan head. Sinks fast and leaves no lacing. Big smoky smell. Bit of caramel and burnt sugar. Coffee. Same in the taste. Not too smoky though. Sweet mouthfeel with a bit of dryness. Very good stout with a nice addition of smokiness added to it. I could drink the stout alone, the smoke just adds a nice layer to the complexity.

355 ml bottle.
Pours a pitch black colour with a beautiful brown, red head. Aroma of burnt wood, some smoke and dark fruits. Flavour of dry, roasted malts, mild smoke, dry wood and some licorice. Medium bodied with a strong, mouth-drying, wood-like finish. Alcohol but also smoke is well hidden, but other than that quite good.

355mL from The Foodery in Philly, PA. The pour is a near ink black with a massive, ultra deep brown head looking near red. Little to no lace. Not a hell of a lot of retention. Similar pour as Plead the Fifth. Nose is not really smokey- more very soft bacon, smolder, salty brine, muted barbecue. Almost would pass for normal stout as the dominant profile is roast, tobacco, and dark chocolate. Nose really opens up as it warms and decants into some pretty lovely soft smoke and smolder. Taste up front is watery and void moving to biter dark chocolate and cocoa. Comes across as very thin for 8%- almost no body. Still, it is very bitter and dark chocolate forward with spicy tobacco. Almost feels like a session stout. Sort of like a miniature version of Bells Expedition if the abv was as low as it feels. Good stuff. Wish it had more body and even more smoke in the profile.

Bottle.  Jet black in color with a small brown head.  Aroma is nice and smokey with coffee, chocolate, and slight campfire notes.  Taste starts our smokey, then starts to fade into some dark chocolate notes, before finishing with a slightly mesquite bbq taste combined with more chocolate.  Fairly thick body.  I can get on board with this.  The smoke never overpowers and is rather complimentary to the flavors of the beer.

Pours silky black with minimal, quickly dissipating head. Aroma is smoke (of course) with roasty slightly sweet chocolate notes following. Tasting it, the smoke is there but takes a back seat to the coffee and bitter chocolate notes. Finish is smoky and bitter and hangs around awhile, which surprises me because it drank rather thin, Really good beer and really good stout but honestly, I have had better examples of smoked beers. Seems to be missing......Something ? !

Sampled @ Øl & Matfestivalen 2011, Oslo. Pours a dark dark brown - near black body with a small lasting chocolate head. Aroma is quite roasty with lots of sweet chocolate and, oh yeah, some nice smoke in here as well! Watery mouthfeeling, its softly carbonated and medium-bodied. Nice chocolate flavors combined with some smoky sweetness. It ends in a light vanilla and burned-woody finish. Good beer!

Pours a very dark brown color with a tan head that was quick to fade. The aroma comes across as a milk chocolate but very well balanced with a smoky malt character that cuts though any sweetness the chocolate presents and finishes with a slight plum character. The flavor ismainly chocolate and roasted malt and there is more smoke than what came through on the nose. This is really well done (unless your a smokehead and just crave a BBQ in your mouth).
Bottle. Black with small brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, little smoke, bitter and a little liquorice.

12oz bottle.  Pours a jet black color with a light brown head and some lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt.  Medium on the palate with lively carbonation.  Flavor is sweet up front, nice bitter coffee through the middle, and a nice smokey finish.  Pretty tasty, although I would prefer more smoke flavor.

Pours black into a Sam glass. Mocha head with little retention crackles and recedes to hug rim. Smoked licorice and soy aromas.  Dry and thin with sweet dark caramel upfront turning to smoky mocha and licorice in the lasting finish.

Bottle. This one has the looks that Tres Blueberry Stout should have had, not that Tres looked bad in any way, it just lacked on the head size. This ones topped by a dense, medium sized tan head, and on top of a black body it wont look much better. Some chocolate in the aroma, but coffee and roasted malts are dominating, leaving a little room for some fruity sourness and smoke. Chocolate, coffee and a touch of smoke in the flavor, as well as a pleasant hop flavor. The bitterness, both initially and in the end, is of both the hoppy and roasted kind. Full-bodied, pleasantly carbonated and with a certain warmth. Sure a pleasant and tasteful one, but I cant forget the Tres Blueberry Stout I just had. 110107

Tap. Deep mahogany with a tiny bubbly head. Lots of chocolate and dark toasty malts in the aroma, but pretty straightforward.  Wheres the smoke? Just getting an acrid burnt toast/malt finish.  Chocolate features mostly if anything.  Medium to heavier body with subtle carbonation. I must be missing something here...would sample again, but not sure I would bother.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 On tap @ Jackie-Os (Athens, Ohio). Deep black, with a minimal tan head. Leaves a decent, attractive lacing on the side of the glass. Very smooth, smoked coffee bean aroma is a pleasure through the aftertaste. Full flavor, but very drinkable. 8 / 5 / 7 / 5 / 15 Re-rate, 1/26/13: 12oz bottle. ABV is marked 7%. Pitch black color. Good brown head, and lace. Bigger body, chewy texture, smooth carbonation. Coffee, dark chocolate, and nice smoked malt aroma, very cool. Nice bitter light sweet smokey taste. Damn awesome.

Brown black pour, thick tan head.  Aroma is chocolate malt, smoke, salty, peaty,  Flavor is salty, chocolate, smoke, bacon, lengthy smoky peat finish,   
pretty yummy
Draft.  Small brown head, brown-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, oatmeal, some smoked meat.  Taste is moderately sweet, roast, smoke, some chocolate.  Medium body, low carbonation.

08-APR-2011, bottle @Sonni, @Ulkløbben tasting, from "Fish & Beer".
Black with brown head.
Nice chocolate nose, but where is the smoke?
More chocolate in the taste.
A bit thin.
I still wait for the smoke. Fine stout, but no way RIS!

A: The pour is almost black in color with a couple of fingers of tan/brown head.

S: The smoke aroma is somewhat minimal here, which is a good thing in my eyes.  Nice and roasty with some good dark chocolate aromas as well.  Not a very strong nose overall, but whats there is good.

T: A nice hint of smoke throughout, but not overpowering in any way.  Plenty of roasted malts with a hint of coffee and plenty of bitter dark chocolate flavor.  A little bit of sweetness in the form of milk chocolate.

M: Medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation.

O: I appreciated the balanced level of smokiness present here.  Pretty easy to drink as well.

Tasted on 4/15/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Armanetti.  Pours an opaque and oily black with an average light brown head that slowly recedes to thin lace and a nice collar of lace.  The nose is chocolate, almost a roasted barbecue quality, a good amount of peaty and smoky malt, and just a hint of vanilla sweetness.  The flavor is chocolate, nutty, peaty and smoky, a bit of vanilla, and some coffee bitterness.  The body is full with very lively carbonation and a long roasted and smoky finish.

Bottle.  Dark black pour, no carbonation and creamy smoke aroma.  Flavor is thick roasted malt, a little sweet vanilla and slightly peppery and more lingering smoke on the finish.  Very good and very well priced.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep brown nearly black with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma is very rich dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee some dark fruits, very little smoke. Flavor starts sweet and chocolatey, picking up some more cocoa bitterness before touches of dark fruit and dark roast coffee. Finishes a touch bitter with maybe a hint if smoke that lingers. Medium to medium full creamy body and a soft carbonation. Delicious stout, had to dock a point or two for the lack of smoke but still very good

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a snifter. Color is near black with a bit of a brownish tint in the light. Not much head or lace. Nose brigs some roasted malt, smoke, coffee, and a bit of dark chocolate. Taste is mostly roast and smoke in pretty decent balance. Feel is nice and dry with a good body. A nice stout, but not my favorite in the numbered line.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-09-2010

Pours thick and dark brown with a disappearing dark brown head. The aroma is tar like with chocolate, roast, and some dark fruitiness. Definitely more fruity than expected in the nose and virtually no smoke. The flavor is lighter than expected and again.. no smoke. Instead I get cola, dark fruit, and a slightly roasted finish with not much bitterness to speak of. The body is fairly weak and under carbed with a rather unpleasant fruit basket aftertaste. Im not sure what went wrong here, but my experience doesnt match up with the other descriptions. A disappointment, especially after the phenomenal Too.

As of the beginning of April 2011, this is classified as a smoked beer here on RateBeer but Id say the smoke is gentle enough that this is a stout through and through. It pours nearly black w/ some deep brown spots of foam. The nose is lush and rich, very chocolatey w/ lots of coffee. An undertone of smoke is present but it is at a level that it could easily be attributed to various roasted grains. The texture is simply lovely and certainly the best part of this beer. Its soft and full, ever so lightly sticky w/ fine carbonation that overall compliments the full smokey coffee flavor very well. The only negative I have to report is a very slight and non-distracting medicinal tinge to the bitterness in the finish. Overall, this is a very nice stout.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is coffe, roasted malt. Flavour is smoked, coffee, roasted malt, hop, cocoa. Full bodied nice beer.
i love smoked beers, this one is a very roasted thick stout with smoked notes added to it, very well made, another A+ beer from dark horse!

Ar: Roasty chocolate notes with just a mild smoke background.
Ap:  Deepest black pour with thick dark cinnamon head that
dissipates quickly, leaves spotty lace.
T: Slightly sweet chocolate up front with some smoke background.
Almost like a chipotle hot cocoa thing going on - very nice.
P: Very creamy body with mild carbonation.

O: Awesome smoked stout.
This sheet is dankness in bottle liquid form. Not overly smoky, and not fake smoke tasting if that makes sense. Went damn good with my flank steak tacos I made the other day.

12 oz bottle. 

It pours a dense black with a tan head that is fizzy and quickly dissipates.

The smell is classic stout. It has an abundance of dark scents, mostly chocolate and dark toffee. Over this is a very nice roastiness with some coffee and smoked malt scents. It could smell more intense, but the actual scent is very nice.

The flavor carries a bit more smoked malt than the scent. It is dark and roasty in flavor. It like you melted some 80% cacao chocolate into a cup of coffee. It also has a hint of caramel and sweetness.

The mouthfeel is super thick, but it has a noticeable prickling carbonation.

Dark horse with another great stout.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-07-2010 23:19:28
Black beer with a small head. Smoked malty aroma, licorice, viol and chocolate notes. Roasted flavor, chocolate, smoke, licorice, some sweet fruits and tar. Balanced finish with tar, smoke and hops.

Pitch black with a bit of off white lacing.  A slight sweet and smoking aroma.  A lot thinner than expected but it might make it more drinkable.  More roasted/burnt malts than Smokey.  Sweet bitter taste as in liquorce.

12 oz bottle from a long-ago trade.  Thanks to whoever you are.  Pour is chocolate brown-not quite black.  Not viscous.  Nose vanilla and alcohol.  Taste dark sweet fruit.  Improves as it warms.  Not gettin much smoke from it.

dark, almost black pour...thin wispy brown head.  Slightly smokey yet more so of a stout, roasty nose with a touch of mildew.  Flavors are roasty but slightly lactic and not nearly enough...or any smoke...except in the very finish, where it tastes like a i just had a smoker all up in my mouth...with his tongue.  Decent, a little green tasting...I need more smoke if its going to be called a smoked stout.

Pours a black body with a thin tan head.   Smells malty, chocolatey, smoky, and a hint of alcohol. Taste is malts, light chocolate, bitter hops,and the faintest smoke. Palate is bitter and thin. Says smoked but there really isnt much smoke to this.

355 ml bottle. Black body with a fine, creamy brown head. Aroma is not to heavy smoke on a malt base. Flavor is mild roasted malt, smoke, balanced sweet, fruity and some chocolate sweetness with moderate and balanced bitterness. Long and pleasant smoky aftertaste. A nice one.

Bottle from Ølbutikken in Copenhagen. Pours a completely black with a fine dark brown head thats making a fine fizzeling sound. The nose is dominated of the smoky flavours backed up with malty notes and especially some chocolate. The smokyness is a bit meat - for a bacon lover that is not all bad. The taste is bitter roasted with a mild but still bitter finish with a burnt sweet edge. The mouthfeel is medium with a slightly oily attitude. Its roasted to the max - and maybe that is a bit too much.

Bottle. Pitch black, brown head. Dark malty aroma. Notes of roastiness, chocolate and tar. Sweet cocoa flavour with roasted maltiness adding a malty bitterness along with the subtle elements of hops. Long, rich smokey, bitter and burned aftertaste.

Poured into a snifter.

3.5 A: Black color. Almost one finger of frothy/creamy hybrid medium brown head. Retention isnt the greatest and lacing is minimal.

4.5 S: Very nice here. Smells more like a smoked porter than stout, but whatever. The smokiness is on the lower end, but it works really well. Good toastiness, black malt, and roasted coffee. Clean, but slightly grainy and dry. Very nice.

4.5 T: Again, smoked porter like due to the lack of residual sweetness and touch of graininess. Smoke again is subtle, but works well. Black malt and roasted coffee again along with some general burntness. Hints of chocolate. Clean and well rounded.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Could be a bit creamier, but nothing too out of whack.

4.0 D: Pretty good beer. I enjoyed it quite a bit. Im starting to think that Dark Horse makes some damn fine beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-23-2010 03:31:54

Bottle: Poured a dark black color stout with a medium size light brown foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of light smoked notes with some black chocolate and dry roasted notes. Taste is also a nice enough mix between some light smoke notes with some black chocolate and a dry roasted malt finish. Body was full with a nice creamy texture and some good carbonation. Well brewed stout though smoked notes are not as prominent as I would have expected.
Bottle.Pours black with a tan head.Aroma is burnt, caramel, roasted and somewhat smoked.Flavor is sweet chocolate malt with some smoked and alcohol notes.Medium body, average carbonation.Nice.

Pours a dark brown almost black with a milk chocolate colored head.  Aroma is somewhat smokey and has notes of lavender and vanilla. The nose is heavy on chocolate and is almost reminiscent of chocolate milk. The flavor is moderately sweet, but avoids being cloying. The palate is slightly watered down and thin.

Bottle.  Milk chocolate malt with light smokiness.  Opaque black with minimal head - pours thick.  Sweet chocolate and coffee malt flavor with a light smokey finish.  Nice beer - not very smokey though.

Pours syrupy and black, with a very motor oil-like appearance. The head is dark brown and dissipates into a moderate lace. Zero opacity in this beer. Smell is rich of chocolate, molasses, and french roasted coffee. Slightly metallic coming through. Medium sweetness on the taste with a hint of bitter at the back of the palate. Lots of dark chocolate, some coffee, and foresty notes. Very complex and rich. Finishes with a lovely linger of molasses.

Bottle. Pours thick black, medium dark tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is light smoke, plus fudgy chocolate, coffee, graphite, leather,  light earthiness. Palate is smooth and medium-bodied, nice smoke plus earthy cocoa, tar, and oddly, some florals. I dig this, but I was hoping for a heavier hand with the smoke. Nice, and the alcohol is well hidden, but I was hoping for more smoke.
Pours black with a tan head. The aroma has chocolate, coffee, smoke, and spice. The flavor is more stout than smoked. Some balance, but I just want more smoke.

12oz traded bottle. Dark brown, silky looking pour with a medium, foamy brown head. Light aroma is ?grape jelly? roasted malt and a little peat. Pretty tasty. The smoke really pops up in the finish. A well built, chocolately, malty stout with a nice touch of smokey peat.

Yet another wonderful beer that gully smuggled back in his bum to share with me, and I have to point out he hid it in his bum not because he had to but because he wanted to.  Brew looks like black motor oil with no cap not even a bubble on the edge of the glass. Aroma is not the smoky beer I was expecting, it has a good solid malts base with light smoke, nice dark chocolate hints of coffee, and both me and Jeff smelt cinnamon independently of each other. . taste is a good solid stout with tons of deep rich flavor, heavy bitter malts that are smooth and thick, coffee and chocolate seem to be in balance, with the smoke being light and stays in the background never making its way to the front of the flavor. Good beer glad I had it, just not as smoky as I was expecting.

12 oz. bottle from International Beverage Co. in Grand Rapids, MI.  Pours black as used motor oil with a thin dark brown head.  The aroma is unmistakably dark chocolate and coffee with hints of smoke and ash.  The flavor brings the smoke upfront while the dark chocolate and espresso linger in the background and are very present on the finish.  This is absolutely wonderful.
Dark brown near-black color, espresso cap. Honey fruit and molasses aromas. Taste deep fruit spice kola citrus and roasty malt. Wine-like with long notes of chocolate, very enjoyable.

Scored via trade.  12oz bottle pours an opaque, slightly viscous black with a thin, beige head.  Nose is dark toasted malts, dark grain bread, some sweetness like raisins, a little smoke, coffee grounds, brown sugar, molasses, a little dark cherry.  Flavor is malty, sweet, caramel, toasted bread, coffee, coffee liqueur, brown sugar, molasses, dark chocolate.  Full bodied with a lightly dry finish.  Really nice beer.  I was worried that the smoked malts would overwhelm the beer but it doesnt, it actually is a supporting actor.

Vätskan ser mycket tjock ut, doften är ganska snäll och rökigheten bara lite lätt så där.
Smaken: Lett och trevlig, brasa, skinka och stark kaffe.
Eftersmak: Kunde gärna varit starkare, men i det stora och hela en mycket trevlig (vardags) stout.
12oz bottle thanks to jtclockwork-pours a slight light brown head and black color.  Aroma is ashy/smoky-dark malt.  Taste is ashy/smoky-dark malt, some earthy hops.

10/18 notes: Color is murky dark brown, with a wispy tan head.  Aroma is mocha, sweet cream, roasts and more dark chocolate.  First flavor to hit is smoky espresso, which integrates smoothly with mid notes of deep, rich chocolate and lactose sugar.  Deep peppery smokiness runs throughout.  Finish is bittersweet, dark chocolate with a light finish.  Great balance, creamy body, semi-dry finish; quite satisfying.

Pours opaque black. Head is very dark brown but very small and dissipates quickly. Slightly burnt aroma. The smoke flavor comes through almost too strong at the start but it smooths out as the beer goes. Semi-sweet with a bit of tartness, plenty of roast and smoke.

Pours black with cappuccino colored head. Aroma is heavy on the molasses and smoked malt, with deep rich dark chocolate. Flavor comes up a bit short, with mellow vanilla notes blunting the sharpness of sweet molasses and smokey grains. Slight oatmeal notes come through as well.

Bottle. Pours black with a brown head that dissipated slowly and completely. Aroma is slightly smoky with roasted malts and just a bit of bitter chocolate underlying. Flavor has lots of roasted notes with a good amount of bitter chocolate. The smokiness is much weaker and only comes our in the finish and aftertaste.
Bottle at home ... black ... thin lacing ... nice rich fruity light chocolate roast malt nose ... ligh smoked roast malt front ...big chocolate ... little foaming in the body ... nice though

12 oz. Deep chocolate with a lasting, small disc of cream above. Nose of charred hickory, mocha, and light vanilla. Heavy body is smooth and slightly sticky. Taste is mocha milkshake, earthy char, and some light piquant green herb.

Bottled
Thanks Patrik! Opaque black color, small brown head. Aroma of milk chocolate, cocoa and light peat. Full bodied, oily mouthfeel. Tobacco ash, coffee, some chocolate. Simple, straightforward, soft. Hides alcohol well.

12oz bottle.  Pours pitch opaque black with a smallish dark brown head that quickly diminishes to a thin film that leaves some lacing.

The aroma is sweet lactic chocolate, fudge, and some dark fruits with a small touch of smoke (as it warms).

The flavor is sweet lactic chocolate and peaty scotch with a roasted bitter finish.  As it warms, a little smoke comes out and the alcohol becomes a bit more noticeable and warming.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied and kind of watery.

Overall, a nice stout with good flavors.  I didnt pick up on much smoke which was a bit of a bummer.
12 oz. bottle.  thanks to jwattsrugger.  Pitch black and light head.  Roasty and smokey stout.  Full flavored and complex. Dark Horse did a nice job with this one.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
All black with a small, staying, creamy, dark-beige head. Aroma is mild smoky, lots of coffee, roasted malts and dark chocolate. Mild tartness. Medium to low carbonation, great dry and slightly grainy mouthfeel. Flavour is elegantly balanced between sweetness, smoke, dark chocolate. Light fruity tartness in the finish. Long, lingering malty bitterness with a slight herbal touch to it. Long, lingering smoky and dark chocolate finish. Very lovely.

Murky black with yellow-tan film that sticks to the side of the glass.  Orange-brown head that dissipates.  Aroma of semi-sweet chocolate, roasted malts, molasses, and mild smokiness.  Taste is full roasted malts, smoke, and wood.  Finishes dry and bitter (from the roasted malt) with a whisp of smoke.  Better showcases the smoked malt than other beers Ive had, but I could still use more.

A: pours a pitch black, with a dark creamed coffee colored head. low retention rate. mild lacing. looks like motor oil.

S: two big aromas of coffee and dark chocolate. wonderful roasted malts. light smoke.

T: great roasted malts. tons of coffee, chocolate and smoky flavors. like smoked coffee beans with some 70% cocoa dark chocolate.

M: full bodied with a low carbonation rate. ridiculously smooth.

everything I have from this brewery is good. year old bottle. pours thick balck with some nice tan foam. nose is smokey but not in your face. flavor is malty and sweet with smoke on the edges.. just peeking in to let u know its there. really easy drinking one of my fav smoke beers

Bottle many thanks to moejuck.  Dark brown pour, tan head.  Smoked malt, campfire, slightly roasty, caramel, definitely chocolate, and some sugar.  Not heavy on any of the flavors, nice and balanced.  Quite drinkable for a smoked.
Thanks Jon.  The smoke aromas are paramount.  Pours black, great lace. above average mouthfeel.  Coffee, smoke in flavour.Above average mouthfeel.
Pours a thick black with a thin brown head. Has a sweet camp fire smell to it. Taste is about the same with some caramel in the back.
Nose Is a little weak, smells of smoke, roasted grain. Taste is rich, perfect carbonation, has a big BBQ sauce taste, weird but good. I farted...

12oz bottle. Pours a thick looking pitch black body with a thin, creamy, brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is rich and sweet with lots of bitter dark chocolates and robust caramels. A good amount of peat and some burnt malts with some earth and brown sugar. Flavor is similar. Lots of caramel and dark chocolates with a good amount of peat and smoke. The peat and smoke doesnt seem to take the forefront as much as I would like, but it still adds a pleasant complexity. Some light roasted malts as well before some earth comes in to help dry this out with a light bitterness. The smoke grows slightly into the finish along with the malty sweetness. Lengthy aftertaste following a smooth, medium body and light carbonation. Overall, a pretty cool smoked stout. Sweet and rich with an even roastiness and solid smoked malt addition. Good one.
Dark brown with little head.  The nose is campfire smoke.  The taste is smokey with burnt wood and a little molasses.
Bottle thanks to dankman38.  Black with a pretty dark milk chocolate tan head.  Aroma is kind of ashy, good roasty malt.  Taste is chocolate, liquid smoke, some roast.

bought an old looking single from the beer store..

no head at all, which makes me think this is probably an old one thats been around the block a few times.

Bottle. Pours a black color wit a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty smoky chocolate aroma. Roasted malty coffee and chocolate flavor with some smoky hints. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish with smoky hints in the aftertaste.

Aroma is rich and very smoky with a chocolaty undertone and hints of burnt wood and molasses. It pours a beautiful opaque sable, just a whisker above black, with a thick, fine-bubbled tan head. Rich flavor is very smoky and has tones of molasses, fine roast coffee and unsweet chocolate as well as a tiny fishy hint. Texture is thick, smooth, oily and just a little tingly. This one is a must!

Pours black with a medium brown head and some lacing. Aroma is roasty with hints of chocolate, coffee, and smoke. Flavor is rich, sweet, roasty, and smokey. Includes roasted, smokey malt, chocolate, coffee, nuts, cedar, oak, smoke, and molasses. Medium mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Very complex and delicious brew.
Bottle. Small head with short duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, smoke, coffee, licorice and chocolate.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a chocolate colored head. The aroma is roasted, coffee, licorice and smoke. The flavor is close to the nose with some additional sweetness. The palate is roasted. Overall a good beer.

Pours out a midnight black, with an awesome beautiful full dark brown head, lacing is very low but that head is magnificent .. . aroma of sweet tar, light 2 day old bbq wood, and sweet whiffs of leather .. . needs alot more smoke for me, the lightest smoked beer Ive ever and quite alot sweeter than i expected but it is a quality brew.. . Not quite up to the past 3 but happy to have tried it... If I wanted this kind of abuse, Id have a conversation with my oboe teacher.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a dark dark brown color.  Interesting aroma of smoke and coffee, chocolate.  Good good stout with a unique flavor.  Lots of smoke taste in this stout.  A first for me as far as stouts go.
Bottle. Black viscous pour with some brown head. Smokey, peat, and barley and sweet malt notes. Bacon and hints of chocolate and roasted malts underneath, nice stout.

Jet black pour topped by a coco brown head. Smells mildly of coffee beans and dark roasted malts. The taste is nothing special at all. Typical malty chocolate flavor, a bit flat, slight bitterness. Medium body and carbonation. Smoked? No real aspects pointing to this. Leans more towards a porter then stout. All and all forgettable.

Bottle from Capones and Frank Smiths.  Pours absolutely jet black w 1f deep brown head.  Nose is rich, drk malt, choco, molasses, fig, blackberry, port, and mild rauchy oaky notes.  Incredibly complex nose here.  Tastes malty, with hefty chocolate, blackberry, and ;ate rauchy notes.  Complex flavor, and a great beer.

Pours a pitch black color and nearly opaque as their other stouts do with a small, fizzydark tan colored head that receds quickly and rejoins the body. Very minimal spots of lacing left behind with some small sediment floaties. The nose shows notes of dark chocolate, roasted barley, dark fruit, rich caramel malts, There is just a slight hint of smoke and almost no hops at all. The flavor follows with more dark chocolate and roasted caramel malts dominating, but some dark fruit and figs come through adding another layer of complexity. There still isnt much smoke at all. The outhfeel is full bodied and quite smooth with balanced carbonation leading to a lengthy chocolate covered fruit finish. The flavor is really nice in this one, but I was hoping for more smoke. Still a really good beer, but I will have to rerate when I get a fresher bottle.

Pours a  deep black with hazelnut colors around the edges.  Short lived, thin light coffee colored head.  Nose full of smokey, charcoal hops, heavy coffee and chocolate undertones.  Crisp, hoppy beginning, smokey/coffee middle, and dark chocolate/caramel finish.  Delicious, but a little thin in the middle.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark black pour with a thick layer of tan head. Very mild smoke in the aroma. Mainly you get the roasted barley and burnt malt notes. Flavor has a little bit more smoke, but not much at the front. Mainly the roasted coffee and barley notes of the stout. Some light peat smoke at the end, but very mild. It imparts a nice flavor though.
Bottle thanks to wedgie9. Pours a beautiful black with tan head. Nose is chocolate chip cookie dough and smoke. Taste is dry smoke, roasted malts and barley, chocolate and coffee beans.

Bottle from the generous CanIHave4Beers.  Thanks, Andy!  Pours nearly black with a thin but brief light brown head.  Looks a little under-carbonated and feels that way, too, but its a rich enough palate to make up for it. Nose is roasty, with smoked peat notes, some chocolate, roast grain, molasses, and nuts (hazelnuts, perhaps?).  Taste is similar, but sweeter... a little too sweet, and not really smoky enough for my taste.  Still damn good.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 My friend Travis brought this one from out of state to the annual Memorial Day party. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a large dark brown head that produced great lacing. The aroma was woody, toasty and roasty with notes of licorice and smoke. The flavor was bitter and roasty with a strong port wine element and touches of smoke and wood underneath. The finish was long, dryish and toasty with smoke, wood and port lingering. Thick and full bodied. Marvelous!

On tap at the trion, the best bar in Fort Wayne/New Hasven.  Generally, Im not a big fan of "smoked" beers, stout or otherwise.  But the smoke here was subtle... a gentle nuance that blended well with the malt characters and created an enjoyable experience.  I ordered it prepairing to grimace and rate... and ended up smiling and enjoying.

Dark brown and opaque with a brown head. Aroma of roasted malt and oysters. Smoky stout taste. Flavor is not at all sweet, a very different stout than many many be used to tasting. Alcohol level is well hidden. Finish tails off and is more watery than one might expect.

Opaque black with a small, tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of smoked malts, roast, chocolate, and some dark fruits.  Taste of bitter roasted malts, burnt wood, light cocoa, fruit, and some alcohol.

Pours a thick, black color with a brown head. Aroma is of some smokiness with chocolate, roasted malts, and some coffee. Thick palate with pretty much the same flavors as the aroma. More bitterness than I was expecting. Probably the best ofthe series.

12 oz. bottle via trade with fidelis83- thanks again, Jeremiah!  Pours a motor oil color, so close to pure black, with a small brown head that leaves a nice film on the beer and ring around the inner edge of the glass.  Aroma of smoked wood, roasted malts, smoked meats, peat, toasted brown sugar, and earthy notes.  Flavor is also smoky, maybe not quite as much, but the campfire and smoked meat notes are there along with roasted malts, dark chocolate, molasses, peat, earthy notes, dark fruits, and burnt toast.  Lingering roast and smoke.  The smell and flavor are nice, but not next-level like Yazoo SUE or Alaskan Smoked Porter.  My main problem with this is that the body is a little thin.  My palate rating would be lower if not for the nice complexity of the notes to go with the smoke.  Still a great beer.

Thanks, bro!  Pours an an oily slick pitch black with a medium mocha head which fades to a thin ring.  Aroma is smokey roasts, dark chocolate, molasses, and oatmeal.  Taste is dark chocolate and smokey roasts.  Mouthfeel is silky smooth.

Pours black, with a brown thick head.  Roasted malts, chocolate and sweet aroma, didnt detect smoke.  Moderate roastiness and hints of chocolate, moderately sweet, some hop bitterness.  Medium body, creamy.  Very nice stout, but I expected more smoke - the smoke flavor came out as the beer warmed.

Bottle.  Pours a deep jet black with a thin dark tan head.  Chocolate, faint smoke, roast.  More chocolate and deep roast in the body.  Smoke is subtle, nice chocolate brownie flavor.  Light warming alcohol on the finish, smooth smoke, lingers a little bit.
12 ounce bottle-a dark pour brown head-aroma and taste of smoke, dried fruit-smooth roasty finish

Black pour tan head that didnt stick around long .... aroma of roasted and smoked malts ... taste of some dark fruits, chocolate, smoked malts and roasted .... good amount of smoke in this beer .... pretty good brew
Black with a lasting brown head. Aroma is smoked and phenolic , with licorice and roasted malt, and a hint of fruit. Dry and roasted flavour with strong smoked notes. .
Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and smoke. Flavour is roasted malt, malt acidic, smoke and chocolate.

Black color; brown generous head. The aroma shows chocolate, roasted malts, cereals, milk, bread, light dust, very light phenol, but no trace of smoke. Good chocolate flavor, with a fair share of roasted malt and light smoke; the mouthfeel seems quite dry because of the roastedness; the body strength is average; there is a light liquorice touch too. The final is well balanced, still with chocolate and roasted malt. Pleasant without excellence.

Bottle via trade thanks to kmurray8621 on BA.

Pours darkest brown with a small tan head.

Aroma is roast and smoke, along with mild a little chocolate.  Good but not super-complex.

Flavor has more smoke than the aroma.  Some roast and milk chocolate as well.  Tasty stuff.

Decent palate, a little thin like the others in the series, but fairly smooth.

This is one of the better beers in this series.  Its very drinkable and the smoke is nicely integrated and does not overwhelm.

Bottle thanks to Tim. Pours a pure black color with a small beige head. The aroma is sweet, earthy, light smoke, peat not meaty smoke. The taste is similar; a rich dry earthy malt, nice peat smoke, light fruit, grainy lots of malts. Rich and easy. Nice.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, April 2010. Pours pitch black with a small creamy off white head. Nose is roast, smoke and coffee. Very smooth and refined. Salty and smokey flavor with some cold coffee. Smooth, sticky and oily.

12oz bottle poured into snifter. Pours deep ruby almost blacj. Small ruby head, minimal head retention. Smells of dark fruits, plums, raisins and a bit of booze. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Tastes of dark malts, choco and patent, as well as a hint of bacon. roastiness on the pallet. decent stout.
Rich smoky peaty goodness and lush burnt grain. jet black with a robust charred grain body. creamy body with strong dry grain, suspect much of the smoke has fallen off

12oz bottle courtesy of badnewsbeers. thanks, tyler! pours an inky, jet black with a thin, but very dark brown head leaving a light, bubbly ring of lace. aroma is excellent with big notes of roasted malts, smokey campfire wood, dark chocolate, and a hint of peat with just a touch of soil and caramel. flavor is wonderful with big, fudgy, dark chocolate, roast malts, burnt toast, and light coffee notes up front that blend seamlessly into notes of dark fruit and smokey ash on the back end. palate is medium bodied with light carbonation and lingering smokey, cocoa finish. overall, and damn nice smoked stout.

This was an absolute treat of a beer.  Pours a dark brown color with deep brown medium sized head. Aroma is of light smoke, dark chocolate, light coffee and roasted malt.  Taste is subtle smoke, rich chocolate and light coffee notes and light hops.  Palate is slightly chalking but not in any offensive way.  The beer is creamy and full bodied with perfect balance.  This really surprised me.

Fore (of Four) purchased at Tiffanys in Kalamazoo last summer.  The aroma has calmed down considerably, not too smokey at all.  Just smells...lightly stouty.  Flavor has a subtle dry smokey flavor after some mild unhealthy age is presented.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.Dark dark black color, sparkling short,  with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown to brown head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, burnt, dark chocolate. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration, dark chocolate, roasted malt bitter, smoke notes. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat. [20100406]
Smoky, roast and licorice aromas. Mild roast, light smoky malts, coffee, chicory. Finishes dry. Nice stout.

12 oz bottle from TC Craft in New Hope, MN.  Support your craft beer retailers! :) Pours oily black with minimal, quickly dissipating head. Aroma is smoke (of course) with roasty slightly sweet chocolate notes following.  As to flavor, the smoke is there but takes a back seat to the coffee and bitter chocolate notes.  Finish is smoky and bitter and hangs around awhile, which surprises me because it drank rather thin.  I didnt think the flavor would stick around.  Really good beer and really good stout but honestly, I have had better examples of smoked beers.
12oz bottle. Pours dark. Almost like an impy stout though palate is on the thinner side. Taste is a pleasing mix of smoke, chocolate, coffee and roasted barley. This was good.
Bottle with Rudolf & Frylock. Dark black pour, oily like body.  roasty arom a with a hint of mesquite. Smoke not overly evident but sllight. Solid roasted malt flavor, well balanced. another winner

On tap at GI.  Pour is black with a very inviting deep brown head.  Aroma is smoke, light chocolate malt, and a hint of coffee.  Flavor starts with a nice dose of roasted malt which evolves into a rich rounded smoky flavor that lingers for a bit.  Finish is smoke and light coffee with hints of cocoa.  Smooth drinking; maybe a touch light on the palate, but thats being picky.  A really well done smoked offering.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, cookies and cream, light roasted malt, slight coffee, and a hint of cream.  I do not detect any smoke in the aroma.  Poured pitch black in color with a small, dark brown head that diminished but lasted around the edges.   Opaque.  Slightly sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of roasted malt, coffee, light chocolate, slight smoke, and light lactose.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Chocolate, roasted malt, and slight coffee finish is dry.  ABV is completely hidden throughout.  Really no smoke at all.

Flaske: Kulsort øl med et flot lille brunt skumhoved. Dejlig duft af røget malt og tørret frugt. Rigtig godt humlebid i smagen der er meget let røget, godt brændt og i det hele taget en fornøjelse. Rigtig god øl.

Smoky, obviously, but the smoke is just one element in a complex but smooth character. This is close to an Imperial Stout, in mouthfeel (syrupy), look (very very dark brown), and lack of much head (though what is there is a medium-dark brown). 
 A hint of licorice, a hint of coffee, a good hint of bitter dark chocolate. Like a good RIS.
 A new favorite for me.
 Er, wait... a new favorite "fore" me. I like cheesy puns.

Pours very dark, almost black, with a small, brown head. The aroma is very smokey, with some usual roast, and chocolate. The flavor kinda reminded me of their blueberry stout (minus the blueberry), dark, roasty, with some woody smoke. A little on the sweet side, with a full body. Pretty good.

Poured from bottle.  Appearance is pure black, with a sludge consistency and little to no head.  Aroma is of pure chocolate with a hint of coffee, not smelling the smokiness on that end.  Taste hits you with chocolate, that aforementioned hint of coffee, as well as the smoked wood / BBQ that is mentioned in the description.  I really like this beer, I would have liked it with more of the smoked malts, but for what it is this is a pretty solid offering.

Dark blackish in color with a decent brown foamy head. Aroma is all about hard roasted malts giving it a burnt scent. The smoke was so subtle that it was hard to detect. Flavor is roasted bitter with dark chocolate comming through. All in all it was pretty disappointing.

12 oz. bottle from Binnys, $2. May 09. Usual solid black in my tumbler, brown head thats gone quite quickly. Just a little smoke in the nose, actually comes out after I sniff the glass and put it down. Some bitter coffee in the smell and in the taste. A hearty stout, though. Mouthfeel is slightly thick. Coffee and some chocolate roast continues in the taste. Smoke is more peaty like a Scotch beer than like a Bamberg rauch. Alcohol is nicely noticeable. Nice finish does offer some smoke, and a tiny bit of ale fruitiness.

Bottle shared by plovmand, thanks. :-) 
Pours pitch black with a light brown head. 
There  is loads of coffee in the aroma along with roasted malt and liquorice. 
Flavour is roasted malt, tar and coffee.

Bottle. Pitch black with a medium creamy brown head. Quite sweet roasty aroma with coffee and smoke notes. Caramel and light chocolate. The flavour is mainly roasty with light peat notes. Coffee, light chocolate and some lactose. Peaty roasty finish.

Bottle at home. Pitch black  brown head. Lovely smokey aroma, roasted, burnes, berries, fruity, licorices, chocolate,nice light and pleasant smokey,  light coffee, light vegetables hoppy. Smooth - lovely.
Dark black color with a big thick dark brown head. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, and coffee. Medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, soft carbonation, long bitter finish.

$2.25 / single 12oz bottle - Looks pretty good with pitch black body, topped with thin tan / mocha head.  I personally dont like the smoked peat with this stout.  Its not overpowering, but present enough on the initial taste to be unsatisfactory.  Nice complexity, but cant recommend as top-notch stout.  Dark Horse, however, does produce top-notch stuff.
Delicious smokey chocolate smell. Tasting the smokiness of the beer with toasty chocolate malts reminds me somewhat of a delicious mocha coffee. Definitely would grab this beer again.

Botella. Black colour with a nice dark brown creamy well lasting head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt with coffee and smoke. Good filling mouthfeel. The flavour has roasted malt with chocolate, smoke and coffee.

Bottle. Medium high lasting brown creamy head. Pitch black body. Coffee cocoa smoke aroma. Roasted barley malt flavor with a heavy carbonation strong coffee cocoa notes and just a hint of smoke. Fair amount of hops bitterness. Long bitter aftertaste.
coffee, nuts, toast, licorice, soy sauce, smoke, black, brown foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation.

Another damn good stout from Dark Horse.  This is my favorite of their stout series.  The smoke is of perfect concentration in the aroma and flavor and adds a great smokey accent without overwhelming the other great qualities of this beer.  Excellent smooth and soft palate.

12 ounce bottle.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch brown head.  Head retention and lacing are both decent.  Aroma is smoked and roasted malt, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, wood, and some dark fruit.  Taste is similar to the aroma, but there is also some licorice noticable in the taste along with a nice lingering smoky and sweet finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy and it is coating with moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is very good, its smooth and very easy to drink as the alcohol isnt noticable at all.  I think this is a good overall brew, good thing I bought a 4 pack of this!

bottle thanks to blutt59.  poured an iodine black color with a chocolate brown head.  aroma was iodine, roasted chocolate, smoked malt.  flavor was smoked malt, chocolate, and bitter coffee on the finish.  body was medium with little to no carbonation.

This beer pours dark as the night, shutting out all the light. The head is light brown, but dissipates quickly. One sniff transports you to a wooden smoke house with a dirt floor and rust, but with the bitter-sweet aroma of dark chocolate. The beer slides bitterly over the tongue and tickles with carbonation ending with a seductive long bitter finish.  This is a great sipper for a cold night, but is also easy to drink. Well done Darkhorse. This is another great beer in the series of five winter stouts.

12oz bottle courtesy of my wife as a Christmas gift sampler.  Black pour with a thin brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and light smoke.  Flavor is sweet malts and smoke with chocolate and a mild bitterness in the background.  The palate is slick medium with a nice mix of carbonation and alcohol bite.  Smokes tend not to be my favorite because the smoked tastes tend to be overdone.  This one added smoke as a compliment to the taste.

Pours a very dark black color with a thin film of a dark tan head that disappears very fast. Aroma has a moderate smokey nose, raisin and plum dark fruitiness, chocolate malt, mild dark roasted notes, mild alcohol nose and a woody note too. Flavor starts off with a very solid smoky/ashy presence, a bitter chocolate bite with an ending dark fruit sweetness (mainly prune and raisins). Brew has a moderately to heavy body with high, fine carbonation and is pretty viscous and sticks to the side like oil. Overall a good brew with a very well balanced taste. A great, non-overly smoked brew.

bottle thanks to Keir, pours black with a tall tan head.  Aroma is chocolatey with peat notes and a light wood note.  Flavor is strong peat and chocolate with light smoke notes in the finish.  Not as smokey as I thought it would be, but its a nice drinkable stout, and the 8% is undetected.

Bottle from sprinkle. Thanks! Nose of chocolate, roast, touch of dar fruit and underlying smoke. Pours jet black with some brown foamy rings. Roast, coffee, chocolate, sweet darker malts combine with a smoke note thats present throughout. Light lingering smokey flavors. A touch sweet/dry too. Medium body, drinkability is high, as smoke remains complimentary. Nice.

Sampled on 10/30/2009. This smoked ale pours an eclipse black color from a 12oz bottle. Small sized, quickly diminishing, tan foamy head. The aroma is slightly smoky, chocolate and coffee. A medium bodied smoked stout. The malts are chocolate and coffee with a touch of smoke. The hops are earthy. Hints of tobacco, old cigars and wood. Nicely balance. The smokiness adds to the stout flavors very nicely. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is very smooth and clean. The aftertaste is slightly bitter.

bottle, by trade with ogglethorp, inky blakc with ruby highlights, , slim almond foam, aroma has a lot of malty chocolate and coffee, flavor is where the smoke kicks in, really tasty roast meat, cocoa, coffee bean , burnt marshmallow and a lasting finish

Bottle from Crown#6, shared with Brother Eric. Pours pitch black with thin fading brown head. Nose is dry cheerios and sour tootsie roll. Taste is smooth/thin mouthfeel, bacon/smoke, meaty, hearty, full flavor. Very enjoyable, different style.

The most intensely flavored black ale that I have ever tried! Makes many imperial stouts seem bland! Completely black color, and modest head. Medium body. Smoke in aroma and taste is noticeable, but doesnt hide the deep roasted malt flavor.

Black pour with a dark brown head. Aroma of smoked peat, BBQ chips(?), roasted malt, and sweetness. The head quickly disapated. Taste is smoked malt, sweet,creamy stout, roasted malt. Leaves a nice creamy sweet aftertaste. Another tasty beer from Michigan

12 oz. bottle - thanks to pepsican for the trade; dark brown pour with brown head fading quickly; rich, creamy nose with a touch of smoke; sweet, almost baltic porter-ish in flavor with lots of sweetness; dry finish with smoke complementary all around; quite nice
BOTTLE: jet black thick pour, no head. Smoked meat & molasses on the nose, mouthfeel is medium/thick, taste is smokey but not over the top. Excellent.

12 oz bottle slightly chilled. Poured black with a small tan head.  Aroma was a little smoky as it warmed.  Tastes of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, with a nice smoke finish. Im really loving smoked beers now and this one was very solid.

2008 Bottle - Thanks motortoddhead! - Pours thick and dark with a small tan head...aroma is sweet cocoa, light smoke, roasted  wood...flavour is dark and slightly meaty...I dont get too much smoke, but a nice amount, with roasty malt, resiny grain and some carob...dry and bitter, just like grandma...

filthy pour, dirty head with a red hue at its edges! aroma is intense BBQ smoke, but without the salty sweet bacon usually found in smoked beers. distinct robatussin flavor that echoes that red edge in the pour. soft mouthfeel with big late bitterness that lingers.

Bottle.  Pours black with a creamy 1/2 inch thick tan head.  Nose of peat malt, light smoke, coffee.  Flavor was very roasty with hints of smoke and coffee.  Long finish on this brew leaving some smoked malts on the palate.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of STLWill. Thanks! Pours a thick black color with a thin head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, smoke and light roasted malts. Taste is roasted malts, nutty notes, chocolate and light smoke and caramel. Faint hop bitterness. Im not a fan of smoked beers generally but this is very lightly smoked which leads to a nice accent rather than a dominant feature. Well balanced, medium bodied. Nice beer.

Bottle into a pint glass.  Pours dark brown, almost black, with a minimal tan head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is burnt chocolate, coffee, molasses, maybe a hint of licorice?  Flavor follows suit, with roasted malt in back.  I dont get much of the "smoked" flavor I was expecting, but then I havent had many smoked beers, so maybe Im not tuned in to it yet.  This is a flavorful, full-bodied stout that doesnt disappoint.  Another fine effort by Dark Horse!

Courtesy of dkachur. Pours inky brown oddly enough and with a thin tan head. The aroma is sweet and roasty with burnt molasses and chocolate. The taste is smooth velvety chocolate and caramel goodness to midway. It then picks up additional notes of burnt malts and a modest level of smoky notes heading into the finish. Yum, tasty, smooth, roasty and chocolate. Very nice brew.

12oz bottle.  Opaque black with a rusty orange-brown head.  Mildly smoky, sweet roasty aroma.  A very sweet, chocolate syrup flavor, with some light toasty smoke.  Cocoa flavor really dominates, some mild bitterness evens it out.  A quality product all the way, the 8% alcohol is expertly hidden.  Some pungency as you get into it.  Great beer, delightfully light, creamy body for a beer of such depth.

Bottle from Paulys in Lowell.  Pours liek motor oil with a minimal reddish-brown head.  Smells and tastes of toasted malts, bitter cocoa, black licorice, and mild smoke.  Agressive and balanced, but I was really hoping for more smoke.
Bottle. Poured black. Nose is roasted malt and smoke. Flavor is a bitter roast and medium smokiness. Not too overwhelming. Not too complex. Fairly easy drinking for a smoked beer.

33 cL bottle. Pours pitch black with a small tan head. Mild smoked and roasted malt aroma. Roasted malt, subdued smoke, light acidic touch. Smooth chocolate and nice liqourice note. Smooth and acidic roasted finish. Lovely.

Bottle.  Pours black with hardly any head.  Aroma of sweet, rich, roasted malt, booze, and a touch of smoke.  Flavor is sweet initially with some light smoky flavors (but not smoked meats).  Weak-ish palate.  Ok, but I like the other Dark Horse stouts better.
7/4/7/3/14 (3.5/5)

Bottle, thanks to tjthresh. Aroma of roasted nuts, chocolate, lightly smokey and peaty. Flavor is increasingly peaty though the level of smoke is far lower than that of most beers classified as such on here. Not that thats a problem, the smoke here is more of a complex addition to a deeply chocolatey stout, and gives the beer an earthy, more roasty, sort of herbal side to things, all seemingly through the smoke. Sort of a tweener in terms of stout vs. smoked, and either way, interesting and tasty.

Bottled. Deep brown colour, small brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, smoked wood, coffee and some mild alcoholic notes as well. Flavour is quite much the same along with some notes of liquorice and chocolateish notes.

pitch dark, large dark brown thick head.
roasted stuff, slight sourness, licorice, salt in the aroma.
flavor is roasted stuff, roasted grains, smoked grains, licorice, coffee

Pitch black with fairly large deep beige head. Aroma had burned malt, dark bitter chocolate and coffee notes. Flavour had burned malt, coffee and dark bitter chocolate. Finished sweet with warming alcohol.
Pours black with a light brown head. The nose is malty and coffee with subtle smoke & dark chocolate notes. Comes across the palate similar; has roasted coffee finish. Very good.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2010 pours black with a brown head.  Wow.  This was good. Dark chocolate, coffee,  roasted malts,  a touch of alcohol, with a nice bitter sweet finish.  a nice meaty smoke layer complements everything perfectly.   a little nutty.  very smooth with a slightly creamy, sticky mouthfeel.  very well balanced.  great beer.  best fresh.

12 oz bottle from the Binnys Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL). I continue my journey down the Numerical Stout Series path. Pours a thick black pour, largely opaque, a little brown around the edges, with small dark brown head that sticks around and laces a bit. Aromas are chocolate, a bit of creaminess pushing some lighter smoked malts, peat, light tobacco, and roasted malts. Pleasant. Initial is a little light overall in body, taking on light smokey, dark chocolate, coffee and roasted malts all in one. The smoke is lighter than expected, light tobacco and peat, but never really approaching the meatiness I was hoping for. A very smooth beer, the roasted malt and coffee display bitterness and roast, light sweetness intervenes, but largely roasted and bitter. A bit more smoke comes through further into the body, but not necessarily in the finish. Instead, I notice it on initial tounge touch. I wanted more smoke in this beer. This is a good stout, with complex flavors, but I simply got greedy and wanted some more smoke. Extremely well balanced. Not bad. Not great. Good.

Pours incredibly dark with one of the dark deep brown heads Ive ever seen.  The aroma has toasted malt, smoke, peat and tobacco - very hefty aroma.  Medium / thick body that is smooth, rich and silky with light carbonation.  The flavor starts like the aroma, but smooth and added richness.  The finish has some spice added in.  This is very good for the style.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick tan head. A little bit of lacing and really great retention. Roast, smokey burnt coffee, coffee, molasses, dark fruits. Big roasty chocolate, sweet dark fruit, nice dark caramel malt backbone, hints of smoke. Lush, nice smooth carbonation. Excellent big stout, complex, very light on the smoke--in the smokiness range of Stone Smoked Porter.
Bottle thx to The Knight. Pitch black with a small brown head. Nice and malty, roasted and quite smokey. Well balanced - great!
