What a freakin STOUT! Pours a black motor oil viscous pour. Not much head, not much needed. Notes of chocolate, tobacco, coffee and smoke. A little sour on the finish, but otherwiese EXCELLENT.

Draught at the pub.  Opaque dark black.  Thin creamy light tan head clings to edge of glass.  Nice chocolatey smoked malts.  Smoke is president but not domintating adding a nice richness.  Dry lingering bitterness.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a thick brown head. Aroma is of light smoke, chocolate, and roasted malt. Taste is of lighty roasted malt, sweet chocolate, and smoke. The smoke doesnt overpower, it just mixes in well with the chocolate and the malt. Lingering taste of vanilla and some wood. Mouthfeel is very light due to the carbonation. Not bad.

12oz bottle shared by Ogglethorp.  Black pour with a thin light brown head.  Malty and roasty aroma that a stout should have, but subtle smoke in there too.  Smoky malt flavor and a roasty coffee finish.  Awesome stuff, because the smoke is subtle throughout.  I dont hate the beers that taste like ham, but I really appreciate the ones that are a bit toned down.

Draft @ Dark Horse.  Pours black with brown head.  Roasted malt, smoke, and chocolate in the nose.  I almost wish it had more smoke in the flavor, I think it might have even had more chocolate instead.  Decent beer though.

Draft at Jerrys. Black with good, creamy brown head / Smokey, roast nose / Light to medium body, some chewiness, zippy carbonation, with good balance and finish / Flavors of roast malt, dark roast coffee, unsweetened chocolate, and just a hint of smoke / Solid, balanced, and restrained.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2009 12 oz bottle from a One, Too, Tres, Fore mixed pack from Merchants.  Pours black with a small brown head that quickly disappears.  Roasty aromas of chocolate with a small dose of smoke.  The smoke comes across stronger in the flavor, accenting the roasty cocoa and coffee nicely.  Smoke grows on the palate throughout the glass.  It falls a touch flat compared to the first three members of the Dark Horse stout series, but it remains a very good stout.

Bottle at DuffmanSWs beer tasting.  Pours black with a short light brown head.  Aroma is lightly smoky with some dark bitter chocolate.  Flavor is the same.  Seasoned wood, coffee and chocolate, very roasty.  Mouthfeel is big, smooth and creamy and carbonation is decent.

draft at sheffields.  split this with nick yesterday.  he observed that it has zero smoked character.  i sensed a bit, but it was extremely remote, and i probably wouldnt have even thought of smoke if i didnt know that going in.  otherwise, the body and flavor were just like the 1 and 2.  that is, thick and smooth, plenty of chocolate, reasonably well balanced, and quite delicious.
Poured black with tan head. Aroma of smoke and chocolate. Good amount of smoke flavor. Not overpowering.

A wonderfully rich and thick beer with red visible only during the pour.  Black and substantial with only a tan ring that leaves light lacing.  Carbonation creates motion on top of the glass.  The aroma is roasted notes with a bit of funk.  Campfire smoke and peat follow and then a bit of fish.  Flavor is powdery semi sweet chocolate and roasted notes.  Some dark fruit, wood, and faint smoke.  There is some sourness and chocolate in the aftertaste.  Very nice.

Bottle. Pours black with a dense brown head. Smoked chocolate aroma with some caramel and coffee drifting in. Full body, chewy, with minimal carbonation. There almost vanilla or licorice component to the taste, along with all the bits the taste inherits from the aroma. Dry finish with some espresso, smoke and ash but in moderate quantities. The smokiness is subtle, so anyone looking for an uber-smoky beer will be disappointed, but otherwise its a tasty beer.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 Bottle.A super dark black color beer with a medium light brown head that quickly drops to a ringlet,leaving just a bit of lace.
 Aroma of dark chocolate, with hints of licorice and maybe dates; the smoke is very subtle,it is there but just a hint.Flavor is dark chocolate,and coffee, the smokey flavor is much more prominent than I would have expected from the aroma,notes of rasins, molasses,and wood as well; after the swallow, the smoke becomes even more prominent but never dominates and the finish has a tobacco and bitter coffee character to it. Medium body with light carbonation and an oily/slick mouthfeel, not sticky at all.Very drinkable,I could not put my glass down.
 I knew I wanted to try this beer but knew nothing about it, I was blown away !  Nice job Dark Horse !

Black pour with a small, lasting, foamy, tan head.  Moderate chocolate aroma with a balance of roasted malt and damp, smoky wood.  The flavor is also chocolaty at first but then you quickly get a wave of dark roasted coffee, smoke, and wood.  Creamy full body with subtle carbonation and a faint astringency.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2009 12 oz bottle. Wasnt really sure what they meant by smoked stout, but was interested enough to get it. Pours a jet black color with a small dark tan head that dissipated quickly. Smells of smoke and chocolate and malt. Tastes of smoke, chocolate, roasted coffee. Very smooth going down, and leaves a residual smoke behind. Overall very good though.

Pretty nice stout. This pours black with a small very dark brownish red head. Aromas of chocolate and smoke with some alcohol and raisins. The flavor has a lot of bitter black coffee character and the smokiness is very minimal. This is almost like some sort of very strong oatmeal stout. The bitterness is great and mixes well with dry fruit flavors. The texture is creamy. I expected more smoke, but it is fantastic anyway.

Bottle thanks to polomagnifico!Pours dark brown with a slight tan head, down to a ring pretty quickly. Very milky chocolate (almost lactic) dominates the nose, but this has some fantastic balance: slight malt and smoke to round off the chocolate, then some nice plum/sugar qualities. Flavor is very smooth, mainly chocolate and some roasted malt, and more smoke than the nose, lingering into the finish. Really put together, and very reserved. It could definitely use more smoke for the smokeheads, but I like the refrain here, and its more a smoked imperial porter than anything else.
pours black with a slight head. aroma is smokey with roasted malts. smooth medium bodied beer. Im not a big fan of smokey beers. I wasnt able to taste any chocolate.

Pours jet black with a 1 finger reddish brown head that has good retention and leaves specks of lacing. Aroma is roast, chocolate, smoke, some char, caramel and dark malt. Flavor is big on roast, chocolate, nice mild smoke, raw grain, burnt toast, over-cooked pancakes, burnt sugar and some dry grass notes. Finish is roast, smoke, mild bitterness, dark fruit coming in late, burnt toast and some herbal hops, some bittereness but just enough to balance it out. Palate is medium, slightly sticky and has a slightly chalky finish. Good stuff.

Pour is a flat looking black with no head at all.  Aroma is some roasted malts but not much else.  Flavor is again not much more than roasted malt and very heavy.  There is no date on the label or anything to tell if this is old but i must have gotten a old bottle.  There is hardly any smoke flavor and with so many high ratings i think i just got screwed.  Will put this on the must try again list.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2009 Found some old notes. (9/29/07). Bottle. Poured a deep brown black. Smoky chocolate nose. Flavors of sweet chocolate and burnt malt. A pretty good beer. Worth a re sample.

Retasted (5/27/09). Bottle pours a jet black with a rich red brown head. Oak and roasted grains on the nose, hints of chocolate too. Lots of milk/lactose in flavor, some chocolate.

Bottle.  Black pour.  This is a delicious beer.  I get some smoke on the nose, but nothing overwhelming at all.  Great chocolate, coffee and cane syrup on the nose.  Flavor is full and wonderful.  The smoked malt give it great smoke tones that dance around the edges of your tongue and dont overpower the chocolate and molasses flavores.  Really a damn nice beer.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Black in colour with moderate carbonation.  Aromas of flint, dark chocolate, coffee, and fruity English yeast. Fairly acidic dark malt character in the mouth, along with caramel, dark fruit, and a beef jerkey like smoke character. Medium bodied. Not as much smoke as I would have expected or liked, but the bottle might have been a bit old. Fairly good nonetheless.
black por with a slight tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and dark fruits. Smokey, roasted malts and an supurb coffee and bitter chocolate finnish. Awesome!

bottle - I finally found a bottle.  It pours jet black with a thin tan head.  The aroma is of dark roast malt, chocolate, and of course smoke.  The flavor is nicely smoked without overpowering the rich roast malts and coffee and chocolate notes.  Excellent smoked brew.

Insanely dark black coloured body with a thinnish deep brown coloured head. Aroma of strong smoked peat, deep roasted malt, vanilla pods and a great bitter coffee scent. Full-bodied; Strong bittering coffee and dark chocolate (~80% cacao) flavour with the smokiness youd expect from the style. Aftertaste shows a heavy body, malt, and a bunch of smoked flavours - all amazing...with some vanilla and oaky flavours. Overall, probably the best smoked beer ive had to date - and truly a great beer to try. More of an Imp Stout than a Smoked, but the smoked flavours are running rampant in this bottle. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle on 09-July-2005 purchased from Merchants in Dearborn, Michigan.

courtesy of retorp.
Bottle has a good year+ age.
Pours deep black with dark brown head / mahogany head.
Aroma has some light smoke that remain on the low side wit dark fruits.
Taste has once again some low key smoke with an ever present mouthfeel of the dark fruits(black currants)  that became more prominent as the beer warmed up.
Some nice roasted malts and coffee with a very faint smoke.
Beer did seem a lot stronger in abv, and had a nice wamring mouthfeel.

Bottle, courtesy sebletitje. Pours pitch black, with a small creamy head and very creamy lacing. Nose is nice and smoky, with chocolate and coffee, and toffee and caramel. Flavor is great, with smoke, some roast and hints of caramel and coffee, and dark fruit ad big toasted malt in the finish. Smooth, dry, extremely drinkable, medium-bodied. Enjoyed it a lot.

Inky Black. Slight smokey smell, along with roasty malts. Smoke aspect is very muted in taste, but the stout aspects are solid, rich coffee, coco and fruit? Maybe. I always like some serious smoke in my smoked beer though
Pours a thick black with a deep brown thinning head.  Aroma of coffee and malt.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee, malt, some smokey bitterness.  Thick oily mouthfeel.  A solid stout.

Near black pour with a brownish head.  Roast malt and coffee aromas, earthy, some smoke.  Full bodied, just a bit of liveliness in the mouth.  Flavor similar to nose, but with a bit of chocolate and toffee or nut.  Smoke is present but very unterstated.  Finishes clean, not real lingering.  Would expect this to stay with you a bit longer.  Another in the line of excellent dark beers from Dark Horse.  My least favorite of the number beers thus far however.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 12oz bottle. Super dark pour, with a small tan head. Nice smokey aroma, also  smells a bit like scotch. Smooth, smokey flavor as well, very drinkable. Good stuff.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: poured into a glass with a dark chocolate look. the smell was roasted flavor and sweet smell. tastes like a Michigan stout but with more flavor!

12oz bottle from Parti-Pak Liquors (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a dark black impermeable color with a  tan milk chocolate head. Aroma is malty with notes of dark chocolate, roasted malt, heavy cream and just a hint of smoke. Flavor is smoky and malty with notes of plums, coffee, dark chocolate, earthy esters dark ripe fruit and  smoked mullet. Full body with a pleasing malty and smoky finish.

Nose is of caramel coffee ash and heavy on the dark fruit. Black pur dark tan head. Smokey malty prunish flavor. Not real sticky, with hints of milk chocolate and coffee. Kinda mocha-ish.
winner for the night.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 11-16-08. Tart aroma features coffee, apricot, dark chocolate, bonfire, charcoal, cream or butter, and fruit, especially strawberry, scents. Pours a thick, nearly black, very dark brown with a golden hue and a small amount of sable to dark beige head. Smoky, charcoal flavor. Fruit juice taste. bitter bite on the back of the tongue that I believe derives from the burn malts but may come from the hops. A bit tarry. After multiple sips, a sweet, fruit punch, creamsicle-like flavor with some lingering bitterness comes to dominate the taste. Smoky, burnt aftertaste. Light to medium body.

[Bottle] Pours absolutely pitch opaque black with a small very dark head that disappears quickly and is barely revivable. Aroma is sweeter than I was expecting, but not altogether that sweet, a touch of woody smoke, lots of roasted barley, and a little bit of chocolate covered cherries. The flavor initially is more roasty than smoky, but the smoke builds until it engulfs the rest of the flavors, especially on the finish, which is also quite dry. A bitter roastiness lingers along with the woodiness.

Cracked open with a little carbonation, poured thick and dark just like it should, but no real aroma popped out on the pour or once it was in the glass.  Nice full thick mouthfeel.  The flavor was subtle overall though, slightly smoked chocolate, which seems to display itself more throughout the glass.  Halfway through a little more chocolate and roast comes out, with the same subtle smoke presence overtop of everything.  Malt is also a lot more present at this point.  Great drinkability, and would love to have again fresh.

From masonjer via trade.  Super dark, semi-viscous pour with a short tan head and not much lacing.  The aroma was lots of smokey campfire, chocolate, roasted malt and even bit of sour cherry.  The flavor was smoke, chocolate, malt and espresso.  The mouthfeel was average which I found surprising considering the pour.  I found it to be quite nice overall.

12 oz bottle generously shared by csbosox. Pour is jet black, oily and inky with only a thin tan head. Aroma of peat, soy and coffee roastiness. Taste is flat coffee, roast is there, peat and smoke are muted, though present. A bit of soft cocoa. Palate is medium, even a bit on the thin side of medium. Overall a tasty stout, thanks for opening this one Chris.

Thanks to Honkeybra for this one.  
Pretty overwhelming.  Smoked ham, bacon, charcoal, and burnt stuff.  Appealing, not subtle at all.  The pour scared me.

Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Smells of cpeat, roasted malt, boozy, caramel, molasses, raisins. Tastes smoky and roasty with some chocolate, complimentary coffee, some bitterness. Nice rich velvety mouthfeel. Excellent.

12 oz bottle:  Aroma has chocolate, malt, burn aromas, a bit of smoke, and maybe some dark fruit.  Appearance is deep dark black with a medium sized fluffy tan head that lingers.  Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, light subtle smoke notes, somewhat creamy, but doughy as well.  Palate is lightly sweet, bitter on the lips at first then the aftertaste is light and a bit smoky.  Overall, Pretty good.  Like eating a piece of chocolate cake with a little bit of smoked flavor in it.  Cheers!

Pours pitch black with a thick creamy dark brown head.  Aroma is pretty nice, although not all that smoky.  Very rich full aroma.  Heavily cocoaish and chocolatey.  Nice rich roasty character and some lingering rich cocoa.  A light smokiness, but it is quite subtle.  A hint of milk chocolate and a sweet brownieish/cakey sweetness.  Very rich oaty texture.  Roasty but not astringent.  Fairly tasty brew though.  It’s a pretty solid brew.

Bottle: (Thanks JoeMcPhee!) Very dark pour with a deep brown head. Richly roasted aroma- dark cocoa, espresso, dark caramel/toffee-like malt sweetness is also evident. No smoke though. Mildly carbonated with a leaner palate than expected. The flavor has some bitter cocoa, licorice and a mild smooth liqueur-like quality. No smoke is detectable, only in a roasted espresso form, and perhaps a wood note. Nice malt character without too much sweetness, but needs more smoke. Still a solid Stout.

Bottle in trade with ford9719.  Thanks dude!
Pours a dark and oily black with a rich colored and short lived tan head.  Smell is sweet and dark roasty malts with a subtle yet noticeable smoked presence.  Taste is pretty rich, chocolately and roasty, but smooth and with low bitterness.  Full flavored roastiness followed by a nice soft smokiness that doesn’t overwhelm the beer.  Medium to slightly rich mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  Lingering dusty dark chocolate flavor along with light smokiness.  Pretty nice.

12 oz. bottle thanks to a trade with yem25.  Pours a dense black with a thin, sudsy dark brown head that completely vaporized after the first sip and left no lace at all.  Pleasant aroma of roasted malt and chocolate with just a trace of smoke.  I honestly don’t think I would have picked up the smoke in the aroma had I not read it on the label.  The flavor is mostly roasted malt with a bit of chocolate and again very mild smoke.  The smoke becomes more evident in the aftertaste and lingers briefly beyond the swallow. Full bodied. A decent stout, but its restrained flavors are a little disappointing.

Bottle shared with GMCC2181, Thanks. Black pour with nice head. Aroma was nice, mild smoke, roasted malts, and chocolate. Taste is similar with a nice smooth finish. A well balanced smoked brew by Dark Horse.

Bottle from stfun, thanks josh. Dark in color decent head. Aroma was smokey.... and roasted malts. Taste was the same. Smoke, chocolate and roasted malt and blended together very nicely. Texture that was oily smooth and easy to drink. I enjoyed this one. Thanks josh!

Brown to black with a large brown slowly fading head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, sweet malt and mild smoke.  Taste of malt, both roasted and sweet, coffee and mild smoke.  For it being considered a smoked it’s not that smoky, which is why I probably like it more than I thought I would.  It’s smooth, rich and sweet with mild lactic qualities you’d find in a sweet stout and finishes up mildly bitter.  Good stuff.

Summary: Excellent chocolate-bodied stout, more ashy than smoked. Aroma: Dark fruits and chocolate, full bodied, stokes the anticipation. Appearance: Black, deep brown only at the edges, a few bubbles of head.  Flavor: Strong mocha backbone; caramel, vanilla, and bourbon sparkle through at the front, some roast malt in the middle, turning ashy in the finish.  Palate: Thick and smooth, with a dusty finish.
Excellent stout.  Pours like oil and smells or raosty caramel.  Very heavy mouthfeel and does taste very smokey.  Try it with ribs.

Bottle courtesy of StFun.  Pitch black pour with 2 finger tan head and oily lacing.  Nose is smoky bacon, toasted malts and roasted coffee beans.  Taste is charred barley, ash, coffee grounds and cocoa with a light smoky bitter finish.  Alcohol is present on the backend.  Medium, creamy mouth feel.  A very good smoked stout.  Thanks Josh!

Poured a black baclk color with a dark tan head. One of the darkest heads ive ever seen actually. Aroma was very smokey with hints of coffe and chocolate. Flavor was also lots of smoke, almost to the caliber of East End Smokestack but with more wellroundedness with the nice bitter coffee flavor. This is great Stuff.

12 oz. bottle (from Bulldog Liquor- Big Rapids, MI) served in my longing stein- poured blacker than a bad night in Austin once you peel away the horrifyingly false facade, yet another one finger dark tan had formed and tried to steal my car.  Aroma of a darkened malt, perkulated coffee that has been sitting warmed continuously for over 24 hours, and... (insert melodramatic gasp here) SMOKE.  Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, malt seems just a little too thin when compared to the other 3 that I have tried, bits of dark molasses notes in the middle are overpowered by SMOKE and cream, finish keeps going on forever like a brainwashed Obama supporter that just won’t learn to shut the hell up.  Definition of irony for today-  "The Blues" by GN’R came onto my  player while I drank this.  While in Texas.  Yeah... sometimes you can never go home when you want to...

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 poured black and thick,with brown head  lots of lacing aromas of coffee and smoke taste is of smoke coffee roasted malts and chocolate.  a great american stout from a truely great american brewer of stouts

Bottle from the Piggly Wiggly. Deep pitch black, touch of brown at the edges. Tannish head. Nose has very little smoke in it, I guess it’s due to it being peat smoked rather than hardwood. It is a pretty nice stout, at any rate. A touch tart and acrid, but very smooth. Not overpowering. Pretty decent, but no smoked...

Bottle via Secret Santa.  Thanks!  Pitch black, very dark brown head.  Nose is roasted marshmallow/burnt sugar, rich roasty malt, some inky darkness that I suppose is smoke.  Flavor is more of that burnt sugar & roast, good toffee, light but present smoke, a twinge of hop.  Long bittersweet slightly smoky finish.

Bottle.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, smoke, and cream.  Pitch black hue with a small fully diminishing tan head that left no lace.  Flavor is salty, smokey, and creamy.  Palate is soft and full bodied.  Very nice and rich brew.  Great aroma and great flavor.  Best of the series.

bottle: pours  black with a tiny bubble brwon heasd that quickly diminishes.. aroma is chocolatey and roasted with hints of smokiness, a thick toffee malt in the background also.  flavour is smoke chocolate and a nice roast flavour that all blend together well to make a god smooth drinking stout a touch of maolases seems to linger around finishes nice and a real treat to tdrink.

Bottle, nice job Dark Horse! Pours black with a small diminishing brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, mild smoke, a touch of chocolate and some coffee. Flavour of mild smoke, coffee, chocolate, some fruit and a mild hop finish. Medium to full bodied. This is very easy to drink and a very pleasant Stout.

Bottle courtesy of wj94. Pours a viscous black right out of the bottle with no light penetrating.  With an aggressive pour, the head was a small, dense mocha that dissipated almost immediately leaving almost no lacing.  The smell had only a hint of charcoal and hickory smoke in the background and was more heavily skewed to the sweet side with roasted malts, dark chocolate and dark fruits.  The taste is sweet up front with the chocolate malts and dark fruit before giving was to the smoky finish which lingers through the finish into the aftertaste.  The mouthfeel is creamy with very little carbonation and just sticks to the inside of my mouth.  This is a drinkable but robust stout that I really enjoyed.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2008 Bottle thanks to miketd, thanks man!  Poured a thick black color with a thin tan head that receded to a ring.  Aroma of smoked malt, chocolate, roast, and a hint of coffee.  Sweet entry with hints of chocolate, molasses, and a hint of woody vanilla that transitions into a moderate roasted coffee flavor ending with a nice smoked malt presence.  Smooth on the palate.  Overall, better than I expected, and a fine offering from DH.

This beer pours DARK, really really dark, with a reddish-tan head.  A lot of smoke in the nose, some chocolate. Taste is fantastic. Rich, roasted malts, coffee, tobacco, chocolate, and a smokey finish. Thick luxurious mouthfeel. I picked this up kind of as an impulse buy as it was next to the register, but it turned out to be the best beer I bought that night.

12 oz. bottle into pint glass.  One of the best looking pours I have ever seen - a black oil pour with a great dark brown head - thicker pour than expected.  The aroma is very chocolaty - dark milk chocolate - with a vanilla backbone and a coffee finish.  Aroma is very full and rich with a complexity of subtle aromas that linger between these.  While the aroma is dominated by chocolate, the flavor is dominated by roasted specialty malt and coffee characteristics.  Bitter dry hops on the finish that work well with the bitter coffee notes.  Medium to full bodied on the palate and decently coating; smooth with very subtle carbonation.  Overall: this brew took me a bit by surprise; it is unbelievably good, but a bit confused.  I am not getting much smoke and would definitely characterize this as an Imperial Stout and not as "A Smoked."  Either way it is a must try.

Pours dark brown near black with a small bubbly espresso colored head.   Sweet aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, molasses, roast and hints of smoke, wood and coffee beans.  
Sweet upfront taste, molasses and chocolate with notes of roast and a slight coffee finish.  Not really sure where the smoke is?   Like a smoother less complex version of expedition stout.   Quick bitter finish.   Medium bodied, very creamy and smooth body with very subtle carbonation.   Yum, super easy drinking.

Black in colour, thin but lingering tan coloured head, some light lacing.  The aroma is lightly roasty, good amounts of smoke, dark chocolate and molasses.  The flavour is lightly smoky, some sweetness, very malty, good roast, more dark chocolate.  Lightly sweet mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium carbonation.  Finishes a little thin, smoky.
While there is good amounts of smoke throughout this beer, its seems to be lacking in body.  No noticable alcohol.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with HogTownHarry, thanks Harry.
Opened on February 22, 2008
No date.

12oz bottle.  Pours one of the blackest colors I’ve ever seen in any stout, absolute pitch black with a medium sized dark brown, bubbly head.  Aroma is chocolatey, malted milk balls, fairly roasty but surprisingly not that smoky.  When I look for the smoke I can find it but if I didn’t know this was a smoked stout it wouldn’t have jumped out at me in the aroma.  Flavor is chocolatey, pretty much just chocolate actually.  It’s nice and good and leads to a chocolatey finish.  Not much smoke detected in the flavor either.  Surprisingly dry, certainly dryer than I expected it to be.  For my tastes it could use a bit more viscosity or creaminess.  Searching for the smoke I do find a bit of a BBQ flavor but it is certainly subtle, just like the aroma.  Overall this is a quality stout.

The Dan Journal #201.  Tasted 7/10/08.  12oz bottle.  Pitch hue with a khaki head.  Oatmeal and fudge aromas.  Hints of dark chocolate and a touch smokey.  Full bodied with a slight cherry, berry estery malt character.  Good roast with hints of dark chocolate and moderate smokey flavor.

12 oz. bottle. pours dark velvet black with brown small head. aroma consists of dark caramel roasty malt sublte smoke. Starts toffee sweet, with dark chocolate, brown sugar. some warming from alcohol.
Pours a jet black color with a brown head.  Aroma is malty, toasty, smoky, roast, caramel, and some alcohol.  Flavor is chocolate, malty, roast, caramel, and a sweet brown sugar finish.

Bottle. Pours like an extremely opaque black motor oil. The dark tan head, with hints of burgundy, is a bit course. The aroma is very smoky with strong tinges of a tart, tanginess. The fruit aroma is like a mix of a kiwi tart and a plum and pomegranate tanginess. It has a medium weight in the mouth with some decent carbonation. The flavour starts with a round dark fruit flavour (leaning more towards pomegranate). The smokiness then quickly overpowers the citrus. Hints of a brown sugary sweetness mellows out the medium bitterness. Towards the finish, dark fruit and soy sauce-like flavours are apparent behind the intensely dominant meaty smokiness. This is so incredibly smoky. It’s like drinking meat.

12oz. bottle, with thanks for Gregis for getting this for me from Indy a while ago, and this finally completes the 1-5 series for me.  Pours a thick and dark black with a foamy dark brown head that diminishes but is easily revived with a few swirls.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, smoke and peat; all lightly present.  Flavor brings out more peat, with some light smoke, roast and coffee.  Not a powerful smoke by a long stretch, but another solid and tasty stout.

This is superb.  Pours pitch black.  Smoked aroma and flavor have a really nice sweetness to them.  Does not end up reminding one of smoked sausage.  Very easy to drink.  Dark chocolate and subtle charcoal aftertaste.

The color was dark black.  The head was thin, creamy, and very dark brown.  The aroma was coffee, smoke, sweet, and molasses.  The flavor was espresso, roasty, smoke, molasses, and hops.  The palate was thick-bodied.  The finish was roasty and hoppy.

Good god do I love the pour of a Dark Horse stout. Everyone I’ve emptied out of the bottle has been ink black, ink. Thin chestnut brown head. The nose is so nice, smoked chocolate, coffee, normal chocolate, sweet, no alcohol, molasses, brown sugar. The flavor is.....roasty, bittersweet bakers chocolate, very very mild smoked character, coffee. I’d count off half a point for the mouthfeel, wish it had been fuller. Nice carbonation though. Finishes roasty with coffee.

A black pour with a dark tan head.  Whoah.  Aroma is roasted malts,  chocolate,  and coffee.  Flavor has more roasted goodness, some chocolate,  caramel,  and wood shows through as well.  Not quite as smokey as expected,  but the stout hanging out here is very nice.  Finishes mildly bitter.

Bottle.  My second favorite of the series.  Pours a dark brown black body with a dark tan head.  Aroma is smoky malt, peat, woodiness, and some chocolate and sweet malt.  Comes together great in the flavor.  Great beer.

12oz Bottle - Trade - Masonjer 
Aroma  Great light smokiness in the aroma with lots of dark malts. 
Appearance  Black in color, thin head and clear if you can see through black. 
Flavor  This was a light smoked stout with a hint of peat and smokiness with a huge stout behind to hold up your fork.  Great stuff.       
Palate  Great Mouthfeel, crisp Smokey texture with a dry finish. 
Overall  What a wonderful beer.  This was a huge stout with a light peaty smoky flavor that made this a great beer.  WOW Can I have more please with my dinner be sure to drink with a fork.

Near black with a brown head. Medium full body and smooth. Great stout taste is blackened malts with smoke and peat with a black malt bitterness to finish. A very good base stout with bonus smoke and peat flavors.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle thanks to 17thfloor. Opaque black with small tan head. Aroma is big smoke, roasted chocolate, a little sweet roast, with only a tad bit of hops, dark fruit and alc. Smoke base to the flavor with dark roasted malt, chocolate, a little alc with hops. Medium body with a little syrupiness. A nice stout with a great balance of smoke thrown in.
Bottle, thanks to Nuffield.  A rich deep black color with a dark brown head.  A full aroma with smoke, wood, chocolate, and rich malts.  The smoked flavor is strong with a long finish.

A black appearance with a tan head. The aroma contains some coffee, chocolate, and a decent amount of smoke. The flavor is rather bitter with loads of coffee and chocolate. The smoke is there but not over the top either. Overall this was a nice beer!
Nice roast, good full body. Slight acidity from roasted malts in the finish. The smoke is fairly subtle.

In short: A syrupy extra-roasted stout.  More Burnt than Smoked.  Decent beer but slightly below average for the style.
How: Bottle at Flossmoor on Pre-Dark-Lord-Day party 2008.  Unknown generous soul, thanks a lot whoever you are.
The look: Black body with a small tan head
In long: Not much real smoke in this one.  More like charcoal on the nose and ashes in the taste.  Body is very soft and so is the carbonation.  Some alcohol presence (bad for a 8% stout) and the beer is syrupy like a 12% stout.  Basic extra-roasted malts with some chocolate flavour.  Overall pretty dry despite the syrupy body.  Very limited fruitiness.  Dark Horse Foregettable Smoked Stout.

Bottle.  Pour is dark, dark brown with a cola like head that sits around 1/4".  Aromas are full on chocolate and cocoa with molasses and a touch of peat.  As it sits for a little bit it seems to start to smell a little more of charcoal.  Flavor is a lovely mix of heavy stout chocolaty-ness and smoky peat notes.   All of this sits beneath a nice vanilla creamy texture that makes it really nice and enjoyable.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. Deep brown (almost black) with a small, chocolate-brown head. Aroma of dry cocoa, fresh ground espresso beans, charred malt and mild smoke. Medium bodied, very smooth. Fantastic flavour - the smoke is mild, but theres enough to get noticed, and it melds well with the big roasty and chocolatey stout. Very nice.

Pours a thick, opaque espresso brown with very little head, just tan lacing. Aroma is definitely smoked and cocoa with roasted malts. Flavor is HEAVILY smoked malts and espresso. Body is medium and carbonation light. Dark horse made a strong smoked stout but did it well.

Dark dark dark. Brownish espresso head. Big malts, lots of milk chocolate. Also a bit of coffee and maybe a hint of smoke. Full bodied, thickness lingers on the palate, but not annoyingly so. Smooth. Just another in the line of fine brews from Dark Horse. Not disappointed by this one.
Bottle: Pours very dark with almost no head.  Aroma of molasses and smoked malt.  Flavor of molasses, smoked malt and coffee.  Very good.

Pour is dark black with an average cocoa head.  Not a lot of smoke noticed in the aroma.  That is okay with me as I prefer the smokiness to be more subtle as opposed to dominant.  Lots of chocolate with faint smoke notes.  Creamy smooth palate.  Rich beer and not like I expected.  A nice treat.  My kind of smoked beer.  Another winner from Dark Horse, which is quickly moving into my top tier of breweries around.

Dark beer with a thin brown head.  Smoke, chocolate and molasses all in the deep, silky nose.  Nice full bodied beer.  Lots of bitter chocolate, burnt toast, molasses, clean wood smoke, and alcohol.  Not greasey like some smoked beers.  Really a well blended, well balanced treat.

Thanks to hophead75 for sharing.  Pours a deep charcoal black- almsot opaque just like thier other stouts- head is thin.  Aroma is toasty- tons of chocolate malt and the smoke is noticed but not intense. Flavor has a bit more smoke, but the chocolate malts dominate- has some licorice, and almost an oily feel and a smooth finish.  Great stout as expected from DH.
Flossmoor tasting. Pours Black with a brown head. Sweet with some druness. Some smoke aromas. Also roasteed malts and dark chocolate. Finish is dry and a bit sour with a hint of resin.

12 oz bottle from Stine.  Black in color with a small light brown head.  Aroma is very nice- chocolate, moderate roast/coffee, some hints of smoke.  Taste is roasty with chocolate, moderately sweet, with a nice smooth body.  Some hints of smoke in the finish, but I wouldve liked more personally.  Overall a very good stout. Thanks Eben.

I was afraid this was going to remind me of cocktail weenies, but thankfully its not entirely true to style.  On tap@ Dark Horse 12/30/07.  Poured a dark, dark  brown with a tan head, releasing notes of coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Flavor reminds me of smoked chocolate, and not smoked meat which is why I finished this beer and enjoyed it.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle from Stine - thanks!  Dark, blackish color wiht a nice looking tan head.  Aroma has a nice mix of smoke, chocolate, coffee, and cream.  Flavor is roasty, smoky and chocked full o dark chocolate.  Nice body and a thick finish.  Good - but not really a smoked.  Just call it a good stout and be satisfied.
By the bottle that was purchased at the breery.  Smoke a bit strong, but well mixed in with the dark malts.

Big thanks to Tytoanderso for this bottle.  Yep, thats a smoked stout.  Lots of layers of greasy smoky malt.  Theres a little bit of bittersweet cocoa underneath, but its pretty much overpowered.  Some raisin and cherry in there too.  Seems to be a nice complex stout with a ton of smoke on top, which mutes some of the flavors underneath.  On the flip side, the smoke fits in with the rest of the malt profile perfectly.  It also builds an essentially perfect mouthfeel that is slick and smooth, but rich and dense.  Really no hops or bitterness to speak of which doesnt lose it any points, but disappoints me slightly, as Im on a pretty big hop kick at the moment.  Im slowly getting more and more into smoked beers, and this is a really nice one.  Very well crafted.  This is the kind of beer I wouldnt often think to buy a sixer of, but if I saw it on draft and was in the right mood, I would definitely order and enjoy the hell out of it.

12 oz. bottle, no freshness/bottling date, sampled in a pint glass. I checked a couple of other beer websites today and they listed the ABV as 8%. The Dark Horse site lacked this info.

L: Opaque blackish brown with a bubbly topped, creamy tan chocolate head the slowly dissipated into a thin sudsy layer. Like all the stouts Ive tried in the Holiday Stout series, this has an appetizing, taste inducing appearance.

S: Right off the bat, a nice aromatic aroma of smoked peat, whiskey-like, followed by dark chocolate cake with a trace of vanilla icing. In the background is a light char scent, the slightest of dark fruits smells and freshly grounded espresso beans. The alcohol is a barely noticeable mix of peat and fruity esters.

F&T: The medium body, while pleasantly smooth, would benefit from more carbonation. The moderate carbonation gives this a skimpy creaminess, plus I feel that it holds back the malty chewiness and flavor. I would also like a bit more firmness in the mouthfeel too. The smoky peat malt is much more subtle in the taste than in aroma, becoming more charred tasting as you reach the end. In the middle milky chocolate and a mild fruitiness emerges, lending some sweet softness to the overall taste. Finishes on a burnt coffee note, like a coffee pot that has been on the burner for too long.

A decent American stout, but my least favorite in the series, just not as bold tasting as the other offerings. Still, I would recommend that any dark stout fan give this a try just to compare it to the other stouts in the series from Dark Horse, a mid-Michigan brewery known for quality beer.
(Bottle)  Pours a black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of wood, smoked sausage, chocolate, some black cherry peel, and roasted malt.  Flavor of chocolate, smoke, cocoa, and roasted malt.

At first I thought this was just too cold, but even as it warmed it didnt really blossom.  Theres definitely a smoked note here, and some frontal fruit suggests a great underlying stout recipe, but even so it had a slightly sour edge and lacked the dimensionality in the mid and late palate.  A little bit thin on the palate for what it is.  Really good appearance, at least.

Pours black with a small dark tan head, a little lacing. Aroma is chocolate, smoke, a little alcohol comes out as it warms. Decent sweetness, something seems to lacking. Thin and smooth. Not great, but pretty good.

Bottle pours black and viscous with a milk chocolate head and some spotty lace.  The aroma is of a distant smoke, roasted malt, and minor hop combination.  The flavor imparts, among other things, walnuts, bitter dark chocolate, long lasting roasted finish, bitter coffee notes, dark fruits and some lactic notes.  Palate is smooth, rich, and coating  sticky on the lips.  Yes, this works well.  I like it.  Much more appealing as it get to room temperature.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 08 Bottle:  This pours about as black as anything Ive seen with a sizeable tan head.  Big roasted malt nose with hints of dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla, tobacco and smoked malt subtleties.  What a great transition this brew takes on, completely balanced flavors range initially from dark chocolate malts and some coffee and meld into a smoked malt beast.  The smoke is so perfectly incorporated without being overbearing.  This a phenomenal stout and will now be a staple.  Anyone who hasnt tried this...seek it out!
Taste of smokey, roasted potatoes.  More cocoa than coffee, more roasted than burnt.  Slightly thin.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2013 Thanks to tronraner for this one. 
Goes into the glass as a very dark black brew with a small fleeting dark tan head.
Sweet smoky malt aroma.
Sweet syrupy texture with a smoky light bitterness in the flavor.
Smooth, very drinkable.

Re-rate 3/11/13 About the same!

[Bottle] Pours black with a small dark tan head. Aroma has a decent amount of smoke when cold, but it is more subued as it warms. Compared to an AS beer this thing has almost no smokiness, but I like that it blends instead of overpowers. There is also a good deal of roasted malt and chocolate aroma in there. The taste is largely roasted malt and chocolate, with a little alcohol, and surprisingly little smoke. Medium mouthfeel with a long finish where finally a little smoke shows through to go along with a roastiness that borderlines on charred. A solid beer.

I love smoked beers and this being a stout was even better,with hints of coffee and a nice smokey flavor with a thick and tastey head,it poured black and thick like an IPS but not overwhelming as one very good beer and enjoyable.CHEERS!

Velvety, oil black pour produces a thick fudge milkshake of a head, which eventually settles to a thin, transparent glaze.  These non-imperial Dark Horse stouts really achieve another level of blackness for what they are.  Aroma is full of tangy, earthy peat smoke and acrid coffee grounds; the acidic, light roasted coffee character seems to give a fresh, lively zest of grapefruit and tangerine, which is odd given that the initial impression is all dirty, wet and oxidized.  No shortage of dark chocolate and toffee malt underneath.  Tastes very slick and somewhat watery; though very full in texture, most  of the flavor qualities are delayed to mid palate and finish.  That tepid first note is one of peppermint and buttery soft taffy, which gains volume and visibility in the muted, roasty middle, and sort of stumbles into dominance after a failed coup of smoky, rough edged campfire malt.  Thinly smoky.  So reserved.  Confusing.  Buttered toast, raspberry jam, nothingness.  Palate is luxuriously soft and full; a rich pipe tobacco smoke in a slow coating.  Its hard to describe how out of snyc that quieted, meek flavor is with the rest of the experience, especially with this soft, visceral and firmly muscled mouthfeel of a bloody, cocoa dusted flank steak.  Finish brings the rustic smoked meats and juicy, ballsy dark coffees without reservations, which gives a frustrating picture of what this beer might have been all the way through with a little more willingness to kick ass.
thanks to bullzeye for sharing this.  black pour with reddish lacings.  chocolate and smoke on the nose.  thickness is great and the smokey  flavor was awesome.

Bottle. Not being a fan of "smoke" beers, I was very wary about trying this beer.  The sell for me was that it was a stout and not a porter.  

For starters, I was fairly impressed with the very black, thick pour.  No head what so ever.  Not very much there with the aroma though.  What is there are notes of smoke (obviously) and chocolate. Upon tasting it, I was surprised, but not impressed.  A very thick beer!  It almost feels like drinking thinned chocolate syrup.  Most of the smoked malt was completely masked by the overwhelming chocolate flavors.  Its almost a little too chocolaty, without enough of the smoke. However, I shouldnt be complaining about this aspect since Im not so hot on smoked beers.  This definitely made me more open to trying more.  Its another solid beer from Dark Horse, but I would rather be drinking their Oatmeal stout

Finally rating this one.  Poured black with a small tan head.  Smelled of big smoke, like a hearty bacon breakfast around a campfire.  Taste was chocolate, smoke, some roastiness, with a dry finish.  Nice and smooth.  This is by far one of the better smoked beers I have had.  Not too big on the style, but this one is very nice.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in a shaker.  This stout poured an oily, opaque jet black with a thin head of dark tan foam that lasted throughout most of the glass.  Some slippery lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of smoke, light chocolate, heavily roasted malt, and also some earthy yeast notes.  The flavor consisted of mildly bitter heavy roasted notes, strong smoke, strong espresso roast coffee, and some mild chocolate.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with mild carbonation.  If you enjoy smoke and roasted/charred malt, this will suit you just fine.

Had a sample of this at the Blind Pig in Champaign.  Got to meet Mike, DHs marketing guy, and Noonie, one of the brewers.  Very dark pour with brown edges.  Chocolaty, roasty aroma.  Flavor is similar, although I didnt really enjoy the smokey aspect of it.  Smokey flavor was not overpowering though and this is a solid beer; this just isnt a style that I actively seek out.

very dark brown, almost black, no head.  not sure what i am sniffing, but it is musty.  full-bodied.  flavor of coffee , and, like the commercial description claims, a smokiness reminicent of barbeque.  i didnt find it all that enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle. Poured black with no head or lace. Nose was peaty, wet earth, burnt wood. Taste was heavily roasted malts, bakers chocolate, & mild coffee.  As the beer warms a bit the smoky peat flavor comes on a little stronger, but not annoyingly so. Low carbonation and a somewhat dry mouthfeel.
Poured thick black with no head. Aroma of meat and chocolate. Lots of smoke flavor from start to finish. Some chocolate but mostly smoke.

2/29/2008:  Dark Horse Fore Smoked Stout pours black with a low level of carbonation and a small brown head that diminishes quickly.  Sweet char, roasted malts, semi-sweet and dark chocolate, and dark fruits comprise the aroma.  I dont really pick up and smoke in the aroma.  The front end flavor mimics the aroma and is followed by a darkly caramelized maltiness, lots of roast, coffee, and hints of dark chocolate.  It finished slightly dry.  There really isnt smoke ( meaty, dry beechwood, or otherwise).  This beer is more roasty with char, high cocoa content chocolate, and coffee notes than it is smoky.  Either way, it is still very good!  This beer has a medium-full body and is smooth and silky.   Overall this is a really good Stout, but it is lacking the smokiness that I was hoping for.
12 fl. oz. bottles from Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #189 for this beer...

Again, thanks to SQNfan for the bottle via trade...CHEERS!!!  This one was a step above the Cream Stout...very similar in terms of the two As, but more Aggressive swiss chocolate, dark-roast Starbucks coffee, and toffee/caramel. Even the label is Aesthetically pleasing.  A rating!!!  If this is Available in your Area, TRY IT!!!

While not as taken by this as some others, it was a good beer.  Dark, alomost black, with a tan head.  Did not get much smoke in the aroma, which is good, or in the taste, which is better.  Just a light wisp of smoke.  Other notes more apparent were roasted barley, dark coffee, chocolate malt.  Flavor was dark chocolate, roasted nuts, and that hint of smoke.  Nice.

Pours the darkest possible, opaque chocolate brown to virtually black body.  A small, foamy, chocolate brown head dissipates quickly to a wispy film with a pronounced edge.  Minimal traces of spotty lacing are noted.  The aroma shows rich dark and light chocolates, chewy nougat and caramel, roasted barley, and some dark fruits.  A light smoked peat aroma enters the fold, adding depth and character.  There are some traditional Baltic characteristics in the nose, as dark fruits and rich, chocolaty malts are uninterrupted by any hop character.  The flavor follows suit, with rich, roasty malts again dominating.  The smoked peat really comes through, blending perfectly with the decadent chocolate and caramel.  Hints of alcohol soaked figs and dates emerge adding yet another layer of malty goodness.  The mouthfeel is just shy of full and quite viscous, with just a hint of cloying sweetness showing after the long, smoky, roasted finish.  What an awesome beer.  Dark Horse knows all things stout!  Great beer.

Fore Smoked Stout pours an opaque black with a tan head.  The aroma is smoky, as advertised, but also kind of sweet.  The flavor is a clash of chocolate and cheap cigar.  After having One, Too, Tres, and Fore of the Dark Horse Stouts, I find this one to be the most distinctive, but not my favorite.

12oz from EithCubes - thanks, Mike! Man, these guys at Dark Horse know what theyre doing. This is the last of the initial quartet Ive sampled and Id rate it on a par with the others. That is to say, its a distinctive, earthy brew thats very satisfying and awesomely drinkable. Thick dark pour, very handsome, with minimal head. The barley malts are immediately prominent in the nose, and they are satisfying. But boy, those peat malts give this one a quirky character that contrasts vividly - and tastily! - with the chocolate qualities. Good stuff, guys!
This was a strange brew for me as I havent had a smoked beer before.  I got the smoke immediately on the aroma and the taste.  It has had a charcoal aftertaste.

Pours a thick oily pitch black with a small light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, barley and liquid smoke.  Taste of roasted malts, dark chocolate, barley and liquid smoke.  Very smoky in both aroma and taste, but in a pleasant way.  Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 Weakest of the new DH stouts thus far. The taste is fine, but the smoke is really really light for this one. Almost an intro smoke stout, I really wanted more out of it. The smoke is present slightly in the aroma, and almost none in the flavor. This seems to be what they were going for, but, Ill skip this one next time. Still, a solid offeringREALLY loving the DH Stout line up so far though! Cant wait for 5!

Deep brown/black in color with a very thin brown head that fades away almost immediately.  The aromas were of smoke, chocolate and creme.  In the mouth there were flavors of cream, milk, chocolate and a mineralistic hoppy finish.  The palate is smooth and finishes with a dry/hoppy edge.
Dark viscous pour with thin brown head.  Slight spotty lacing with nice roast and smoke aroma.  Chocolate, coffee, smoked malts, and hops.  Full bodied with light carbonation.

Pours inky black with a mostly receding foamy mocha head. Aroma of chocolate, smoky roast, and light notes of Guatemalan coffee. Taste is chocolate, sweet roast, light smoke and coffee. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation. Very similar to the Dark Horse Oatmeal and Tres stouts, which are also quite excellent.

12oz Bottle pours out a great black topped with a very small tan head. A great aroma of sweet chocolate and great roast malt. Tast of a light smoke. More sweet and bitter coffee than smoke. Pretty good overall. And gets better as it warms up Thanks Secret Santa.

bottle......pours like the others in the stout series.  almost black with a medium brown head....weak nose of chocolate and roast with very little smoke characteristics....tastes similar to too with just an added sense of smoke which i thought would have been more prevalent.....out of the four, i enjoyed tres the most and this one the least of them all.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 Bottle - Pours pitch black with a tiny brown head that disappears quickly.  Nice roasted coffee flavor.   Little carbonation.  Only dissapointment is that the mouthfeel is almost too smooth.  It needs a legacy, something to remember is by.  However overall a very nice beer.  The tiny Darkhorse brewery always impresses.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a smooth tan head.  Nose is faint grape, coffee and light smoke.  Creamy mouthfeel with mild carb.  Milk chocolate, grape Nehi and black coffee.  A sweet smoke ties things together.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2007 Pours black with a minuscule brown head that immediately reduces to a mocha ring clinging to the edge of the glass. The nose is a sweet blend of roasted malt, chocolate and light peat. Medium-bodied, yet fairly thin, the mouthfeel is silky on the tongue until you swallow when some assertive carbonation pops out briefly transitioning into a lightly dry, roasted finish. The flavor follows the nose: sweet, roasted malt with solid notes of bittersweet chocolate and a light, peaty smokiness. Like the "Tres", I think this beer is listed in under the wrong style. The "smoke" in this beer is only a minor contributor to the character of this beer, but as its name includes the word "smoked" Im not surprised to see it labeled as such. After trying the 4 "smaller" Dark Horse "Holiday Stouts", Id have to say that these guys definitely know how to craft amazing stouts. Along with Bells and Founders, Dark Horse has given stout-lovers several solid examples of why Michigan has become a Mecca for beer geeks.
bottle thanks to ford9719. poured a very dark brown.  smoky brisket smell. very meaty taste

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of chocolate and grapefruit, combined with light notes of smoke. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of roasted malt and chocolate, leading to a slightly bitter finish.

Bottle from SpudClampDawg. Black with burgundy hue. Great roasted malt, light smoke,and some dark chocolate aroma. This is one good looking beer. The taste was the same with silky smooth texture. Impressive. DarkHorse makes damn fine beers.
Black colour with a brown head. Roasted, coffee bitter aroma with a light chocolate sweet note. Coffee bitter flavor with fruity notes and hints of a chocolate sweetness.

Poured opaque black with a thin brown head.  Sweet and roasty aroma with coffee notes.  I didnt find the smoke to really be too big.  The roast actually hid it some.  The flavor was roasty with mild smoke and coffee on the tail.  Medium bodied.

12 oz bottle I think BrianK brough this to Dickinsonbeers, thanks Brian (I think). Poured a super pitch black but unfortunately it was as headless as Ichabod Crane. Great aroma of espresso, tar, nicotine and smoke. Super thick full bodiy with barely any carbonation. Not sure if it was slightly flat or if that was the brewers intention. Either way this was a super beer and if it was flat oh my god someone please get me a carbonated bottle because this rating would go through the roof.
I thought this was the best of the dark horse stouts, very smokey.  Poured pitch black.  Definately worth trying

12oz bottle via trade with someone, thanks.  Pours black with light brown thin head.  Nose is very smoky and roasty.  Taste is really nice, full of smoke, coffee, toffee, and chocolate.  This is better than one, though I have a special place in my heart for tres.

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>EithCubes, thanks Mike!) Burnt molasses and smoke...Pours thick and black - black like very well-used motor oil. One and a half fingers of brown head recedes to a pretty-well lasting thin layer. Aroma like lightly burned molasses and light smoked wood, kind of sweet. Mouthfeel pretty thick, almost oily, nice. Flavor is burned dark molasses with woodsmoke. Some grassiness in finish which is only thing I didnt like. Nice thick molasses and smoke. Yum.

Dark Horse knows how to make a stout and this stout incorporates a nice smokiness. Black pour with short tan head. Light smoky aroma and much more stout characteristics in the nose: roast, chocolate, cherries. Nice. The flavor is modately sweet, lightly bitter and moderately acidic. Nice touch of smoke throughout. Slightly tart finish. Medium body and adequate caronbation. I enjoyed this as a stout and the delicate smoke was a plus.

12oz. Bottle the wife got on Wi trip. Sweet tobacco along with burning campfire wood aroma. Black body with dark chocolate thin head. Flavor was sweet and alocohol was noticable at the start. Got a good sweet malted chocolate along with some wood and tobacco in the flavor. Sweet dry coco left on the palate. Smooth enjoyable brew.

Bottle. Aroma of roasted marshmallow, molasses, leather and smoked wet wood. Pours black with a thin ruby brown head. Light smoke at first on the tongue. Lots of sweet, lightly roasted malt. Some coffee. A nice bitter (not hoppy) finish. The smoke starts to assert itself as the beer warms. Creamy with average carbonation.

Opaque with no head.
Aroma is mollases, dark chocolate, caramel.  Taste is dark chocolate, butterscotch, light smokiness.  Viscous mouthfeel.

12 oz. bottle via trade with njhcnwk - Pours a thick black color with a thin tan head that faded pretty quick.  Very little carbonation.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and smoke (peat).  Flavor is a lightly sweetened, smokey chocolate.  Palate is a little thin.  Light to medium body.  A good beer.  Thanks Brian.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2007 12 Oz Bottle. Oily density spills from the glass in viscous splendor. Thin rim of sweet Virginia pipe tobacco. Aroma has a suave and smooth rough salted oak and charcoal. Deeper there is a rich, musky earth spiced with whiskey splendor and hints of barbecue. Deep and complex. Flavor carries more of a dry stout character, but is nicely highlighted with grill char, sweet fish marinade, long drying coffee air, and some flatter ocean tastes. Carboniferous and yet higher with bits of brandy marinated fruit, nuts and nice general malt figures. Long smack in the middle of dry and sweet, but generally enjoyable. I guess as a Smoked this doesnt really excel all that much as Im not grabbing that much smoke, but its a nice stout twinged with those aromas and flavors.

light smokey roasted malt aroma with a touch of sweet licorish, 
lots of roasted malt flavor, roasted leads to bitterness and a long bitter finish, nice smokey character shows up after a while and balances with everything else, smoke and roast create a nice coffee character
