Dark and inky pour with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, smoke, and figs. Smooth and full bodied. Taste is roasty malt, smoky ash, coffee, berries, and a tasty nuttiness. Very interesting.

Slightly opaque black pour with a rather small reddish-tan head.  Chocolate, smoky aroma with coffee and licorice notes.  Full bodied. Low carbonation. Roasty, smoked flavor up front.  Middle brings out a bit more coffee and leads to a bitter finish.  This is a good smoked beer, not in your face agressive but a nice complement to the coffee and chocolate.

Pours hazy medium black with a frothy light brown head.  Aroma is heavily malty of bread and cookies, with hints of smoke.  Flavor is balanced twords sweet, smoke, coffee and chocolate are dominate flavors.  Medium to full bodied, creamy and flat.

12 ounce bottle from Bello Vino in Ann Arbor, MI (June 2007), served at cellar temperature from a Maudite glass.  Inky-black and totally opaque under strong light, with a smallish dissipating dark chocolate head....smokiness is very restrained in the nose, a disappointment to this rauch-lover but whats there is nice:  lots of dark chocolaty roast, a bit of espresso, cherries, and then...wait....the peaty, earthy notes come through after a couple of minutes....nice.....the body is quite rich, decadent almost, thick and chocolate-malty with a light fruity-yeasty component most prominent in the middle, a touch of tart apple-cherry juice towards the finish, and a quite dry woody/bitter chocolate finish....the mouthfeel is a touch cardboardy at the end initially but it brightens up and the dullness recedes after a few sips....this is one of the least smoky of smoked beers Ive had, and I find it hard to place in the stout family: not quite complex enough as an Imperial, not fruity or vinous enough for a Foreign stout, not really sweet.....all that said, the balance is elegant, its quite drinkable and enjoyable, whatever one calls it, and Im quite happy to have it after a couple of years of fruitless looking.
Bottle. Very dark brown colour allmost black with a little head. Aroma of roastedness and hints of smoke. Flavour of roastedness, chocolate, coffee and little smokeness, very nice and smooth.

This pours out thick and dark brown with a smallish cocoa head.  Nice rauch aroma, not meaty like the Bamberger brews, but having a woody smokiness that smoothly complements the roasted malt, barley, and coffee scents.  The flavor is that of a solid, roasty tasting Stout, having the add-ons of some dark bittersweet chocolate and minced hard nuts.  The smoke is there, but in a supportive role.  Pretty decent.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine and Spirits, Whitefish Bay, WI<font size=-1>

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a small tan head that disappears quickly leaving only an outer ring.  The aroma has many stout qualities: strong malt backbone, chocolate, a hint of molasses, but not much smoke.  The flavor exhibits many of the characteristics of the aroma.  This is a good stout.  The roasted malts, chocolate, dark fruits are all present.  The smoked flavor shows up late into the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium-full and is sliky smooth going down.  I like this one for the stout that it is, not the smoked as it is classified.
Bottle. A black beer with a brown head. The aroma is of chocolate, dark fruits and smoke, so is the taste, but light sweet. Medium body with a dry finish.

Pours a deathly dark dark brown up there with imperial stouts with a rapidly vanishing dark tan head, no head at all in under 30 seconds.  The nose is standard big ass stout with just hints of smoke.  Sweet licorice and roast.  Bits of herbal chocolate.  A flat viscous body that while subdued, had some life.  Reminiscent of Founders Breakfast Stout.  Big roast chocolate and alcohol.  Some chocolate.  A bit of fruity roast like a good cup of coffee.  The nose doesnt hold the smoke as much as the flavor.  Over the Breakfast Stout backdrop with licorice theres a bit of that bandaidy smoke flavor.  Also a bit of diacetyl, befitting the style.  The finish is strong with licorice and herbs.  Not a bad beer at all.

Black w/ brown bubbles. Smokey, roasty aroma of espresso & dark, bitter chocolate w/ notes of licorice. Thick, creamy feel. Flavour is roasty w/ a sweet underlying chocolaty, butterscotch maltiness. Finish is mildly smokey.

Smoked stout?  Really?  The smoked character is certainly not the central piece to this beer.  I find it more of a complimentary piece that accentuates the heavy malt backbone.  As far as the stout characteristics are concerned, I find it pretty well done.  Surprised at the viscosity that this one displayed.  Good notes of chocolate and dates with a bit of vanilla dancing on the tongue.  Again, the body and mouthfeel are unexpectedly chewy.  A bit oily in fact.  Not bad, but certainly no smoked beer.

Bottled.  Poured a deep, inky black with a swirly dusting of deep brown head.. leaving a light ring.  Aroma was of rich, deep, roasted chocolates and dark fruits with just a subtle hint of smoke.. sweet, herbal notes appear as it warms up a bit.  Flavor has more rich, almost burnt chocolate at the core with plum skins and light smoke eminating outward.. some mild charred wood with mild smoke and vanilla riding through the finish.. tasty stuff!  Heavier-bodied with a solid feel on the palate... medium, tacky-sweet chocolate finish.  Good one!
nearly black body with a quickly disapearing tan head. Mild aroma of nothing in particular.  Slightly bitter roasted aroma with some coffee to it. Not that exciting, really.

Bottle.
Black coloured with a beige head.
Roasted aroma of chocolate, coffee and yeast with notes of smoke.
Roasted flavour of chocolate, cocoa and coffee with notes of smoke.

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Brownish dense head. Sweetness, roast, fruits, chocolate and some light smoke in the aroma. Flavour as well is very vaguely smoked. Roast. light coffee and chocolate is notable. Meidum bodied. Dry. Light bitter and roasty and. As a smoked, its not very good, but as a stout it quite delicious.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours completely opaque black with a small, light brown head. Very burned, ashy nose. Medium body where the very burned ashy malt accents reappear - but the smoke can hardly be detected. Has a touch of tartness, probably from the malts. Some malt astringency. 270607
Bottled. Black coloured. Roasty malts and chocolate in the aroma. Very roasty flavour with loads of coffee notes. Not very smoky. Rather dry finish.

Thanks to pantanap for the bottle. Pours near black with a very small head that quickly dissipates. No lacing. Aroma of coffee and smoke. Much heavier smoke than some of the other reviews are saying. Tastes a bit sweeter, chocolate mixed in. Medium/heavy body. Bitter and mostly dry finish. Very nice smoked beer.

Bottle: Black, tan head and no lacing. Nose of bright sweet roast and chewy malts. Some hop, dry and dusty, not much smoke, more like burnt toast. The flavor isnt that special, just some char and alcohol. Tons of cocoa and mocha. Finishes stouty.

12oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a pitch-black, oily appearance; medium tan head with a thin perimeter of bubbles.  Dense, smoky and charred malt aroma; dark chocolate.  Medium carbonation.  Viscous, oily mouthfeel: plenty of smoke and dark chocolate; dense, chewy goodness, with some nuts; excellent smoke character.  Medium, smoky and dry chocolate finish.

Bottle at 48F. Poured dark brown with an average brown frothy head that was mostly lasting with very good lacing. Moderate chocolate smoke malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Medium bittersweet roasted smoked flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Complex standout beer.

12-oz bottle provided via trade with Duane.  Pours opaque with spare to no head, no lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (toasted, roasted, caramel), average hops (grass), heavy yeast (dough, leather) with notes of prune, tar, charcoal and smoke.  Full bodied, creamy texture, flat carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Long duration, light sweetness and acidity, moderate bitterness; heavy roasted, smoked malt flavor.

Wow, that a lot of sludge in the bottom of the bottle. Pours black, with a minimal brown head. But a tiny whiff of smoke, and then a chocolate and a lot of coffee and then another touch of, say, hickory or something. Big coffee flavors and an understated note of woodsy smoke. Earthy, dry finish. Thanks to ogglethorp for the trade!

Small brown head, good retention with a skimpy lace. She,s black. Nose is lightly smokey, peaty, grainy malts and a touch bready. Body is medium, oily on the palate with a fair amount of carbonation. Plenty of smoke flavors, light roast, a little bacon, caramel and chocolate hiding in there. Finish is dry, roasty and lightly smokey. Thanks to ogglethorp for the trade!

Bottle:  Dark brown pour with a smaller tan head.  Nose is roasted malt, coffee, and a light smoky presence.  Even hints of molasses.  The taste is a blend of roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, brown sugar, and light smokiness.  Finished dry.  Nice how the smoke is complimentary rather than dominant.  Thanks Eithcubes.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 Original Rating 5/25/07:  The last of the series Skyview was gracious enough to share with all of us.  Black color with no head.  Very weak smoke aroma.  The taste is very subdued, with just some smoke and a generally smooth, slightly dry malt flavor.  Not bad, but Id like to have way more smoke out of a Smoked beer. 6/3/6/3/13  Re-rate 4/22/08:  Black color with a thin head.  Smokey and some oak aroma.  Lots of smoke, roasted barley and some coffee.  The smoke struck me as more beechwood with a little peat.

Courtesy SoLan.  Just pure oil pouring into the glass.  Pitch black with almost no head.  get some of that smoky bacon aroma typical of moast smoked beers.  I love it.  Backed by some chocolate and roast as well.  Not quite as smoky in the taste as in the nose, but it definitely is there.  Nice rich, thick mouthfeel, coats the palate with a warm roastiness.  Nice full body on this beer.  A little chocolatey, with some good nutty walnut flavors too.  Good stuff.

For a smoked beer, there is really no smoke at all.  There is so little of it that the smoke is only perceptible because I am looking for it. A little coffee and touch of chocolate.  Medium sweet malt base and medium palate.  The least impressive of the 1-4 beers.
Aroma of chocolate and some smoked malt. Flavor was real sooth and light. Pretty black with a pretty good descent head. A real light smoke to it flavor with some maltiness to it.

12-oz. Thanks, SecretSanta! Pours a deep opaque black without any head. No lace. Precious little aroma--some woodsmoke and thats about it. Not a real big body or big attack; very little carb and the flavor leans a bit much to the smoky side without other elements to balance it. Its a bit watery as well. Pretty much a middle of the road smoker.

Thanks to skyview for sharing.  A nice chocolate nose with the faintest smoked characteristic.  Chocolate flavor with the aftertaste Id expect of a smoked beer but no smoke in the actual body.  A very good beer but disappointing from the lack of smoke that I was hoping for.

Bottle shared by sliffy. Dark thick pour with almost no head. Aroma of smoked/roasted malt, bakers chocolate and light caramel. SMokey malts fill the flavor backed with bitte3r chocolate and dry coffee. Thick body, bittersweet and smokey throughout with a smokey/roasty finish.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Rileys Wines of the World in Madison, WI. Pours a dark near opaque brown (lightest of the four stouts) brew with a small fast diminishing head. Sparce lacing. Aroma of milk chocolate, a touch of coffee, caramel, molasses, and pepperoni. Not much smokiness in aroma. Taste is when the smoke flavor kicks in. Taste is chocolate, full body, toasted malt and a touch of peat. Finish is syrupy, lightly carbonated and a touch of bitter aftertaste.

Bottle: Finally got to try this one, pours black with a tan head. Aroma, smoke and chocolate, some brown sugar. Flavor, more smoke and chocolate, roasted malts, some earthy notes. Medium bodied. good stuff.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Purchased at Rileys Wines of the World in Madison, WI.  Pours a completely opaque, dark black color with a thin layer of fine bubbled tan head that quickly dissipates to a thin brown ring.  Aroma of toasted hazelnuts and light charcoal briquette smoke blends mildly with some organic brown sugar and dark chocolate.  Pleasant dimensions, but a little bit too subtle to be as enticing as it sounds.  Light to medium bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel; a bit undercarbonated.  The smoked malt is a great touch; its subtle enough to add a satisfying layer of complexity without going out of control.  Almost a little bit conflicting, as the juicy meatiness of the smoke conflicts with the dry roast bitterness of the roasted malt.  Dark black chocolates and heavily roasted coffee linger with some charred alderwood.  Dry, ashy finish.  Like the other beers in this series, I feel this one could use a bit more mid-malty chewiness.  Good execution and potential, but needs aa bit more body and malt complexity for my tastes.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2010 Bottle. Pours pretty darn black with a little bit of a brownish head. The nose is chocolatey with a bit of toffee and peat. Im shocked to see 8% listed here. Dark Horse keeps surprising me with that kind of thing. The flavor is filled with chocolate, nuts, coffee and a finish like barbeque sauce. I dont get a lot of the meatiness or smokiness, it really is kind of tangy like a sauce, but even that is minimal. Id say this is a stout first, a smoked beer second.

[April 01, 2010]

Bottle from Marion Street Cheese Market. This is a pretty good example of a smoked stout. It is bold and roasty with plenty of meaty flavors to accompany the more typical notes of chocolate and coffee. I could use more smoke in this beer. Any campfire or bacon flavor is not super strong, more an accent to the malts.

12 oz bottle. Pours syrupy thick black with amber at the extremities and an orange- brown head. The aroma is very chocolatey with some hints of hickory and a little bit of espresso. The flavor is bitter chocolate, coffee grounds, woody hops. Some hickory notes come out toward the finish, though more like wood chips than the smoke. Some ash and charcoal in the aftertaste. Very drinkable.

Thanx to Ogglethorp for this.pours black and thick like 20weight. No head formed but still had carbonation on the tounge.Lots of chocolate and smoke aroma.Mouthfeel was silky.Flavors of smoke, coffee and chocolate, close to a liquid campfire.finish was a little warming but overall delicious.

Bottle shared graciously by Slob. Appearance was brown to black, clear brown (not reddish or mahoganey) edges, weak lacing, especially for a stout. The aroma was smokey, barbecue, burnt peat, even some light grassy notes. The flavor was burnt, smoke, choco-cocoa, peaty, grassy, very similar to a scottish ale with some ash in it. The mouthfeel was silky and oily. This one didnt win me over, but it was a neat experience and one that Im yet again in-debted to my good tastin bud, Bert. Thanks, Bert!

Deep chocolate aromatic nose.  Even the pour its self is black.  Thin tan head, if you can call it that.  This is some serious stout.  A little chocolate up front.  BIG long somewhat suripy toasted carmel and malted bitter ending.  Nice warm lingering bitter aftertaste.  Profile remains constant to the bottom of the glass.  A serious stout for dark beer lovers.

Bottle. Thanks to solan for sending me this one. Pours a thick black body with a nice thin head. Aroma is of chocolate, malt, nutty. Flavor is of bitter chocolate, smokey malt taste. Sugary and slightly dry. Very smooth and the 8% is undetected. Nice brew, this one hit the spot.

Botle from the pops. This shit definitely black. Small tan head that fades. aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, smoke (but only cause I know it is supposed to be there). Flavor is full with light chocolate, coffee, hops, and a little more smoke than the nose, but still not overwhelming by any means. I like my smoke controlled. I smoke enough as it is. This is a very drinkable "smoked" beer. And I like that. It makes this style accesible.

jayg picked up a 6er for me on a recent trip to the midwest, thanks Jay. Black. Brown edges. Small light brown layer of foam. Flavor and aroma of roasted malt, smoke, dark and milk chocolate. Medium body, balanced carbonation. Very good, very drinkable.

12oz - Aroma is roasted dark malts, chewy dark chocolate and a touch of ash.  Pours black with a medium dark brown head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma with a nice smokey aftertaste.  Palate is sticky and chewy.  That touch of smoke makes it stand out in stoutland, but not much.

12 oz bottle. Poured a thick opaque black color. Head was almost nonexistent. What bubbled up was a light brown color, but it didnt last very long and didnt leave any lace. Smelled very similar to the smoked turkey I put on my sandwiches. I also noted some malty molasses and a whiff of dark chocolate and watered down coffee. Slightly sweet on the tongue with a satisfying, thick stouty mouth feel. Carbonation was on the lighter side. The smoke is less pronounced in the flavor and gives way to a rich, chocolatey malt. There is a touch of roasty bitterness at the end accompanied by delicate acidity. Good stout.

Bottle.  Aroma of heavy roasted malt and dark chocolate, notes of coffee and tarry black malt with a light whisp of tobacco smoke/ash.  Soul-suckingly black pour, opaque and among the darkest Ive poured.  Head is paper-thin and dark brown.  Viscous, full body is silken and dry with strong, tangy stoutsour in the main and light sour cherry in the end.  Loads of oily dark malt in the taste with some ashtray and faint malted milk.  Aftertaste lightly acidic and increasingly sour, but still moderately dry and chocolaty.  Light hop bittering.  Alcohol not detected.  Well-blended and delicious!

Viscous black pour takes some coaxing to create a thick, tan head.  Charred hickory, wet earth, stale pipe tobacco and bitter chocolate are immediately apparent in the nose, leading into the equally malty body.  Earthy, burnt malts and a creamy mouthfeel create a heavy, but enjoyable body.  The smoke is more dimensional though, gaining depth with hints of liquid smoke, toasted oak and campfire.  Bravo to this whole line of really drinkable, complex stouts!

Big thanks to Styles for trading this to me. Pours black with small dark brown head. Nice aroma of light smoke, burnt  cocoa and nutty malts. Flavor is of bitter roasted malts, mellow smoke and a touch of coffee. Rich and creamy. Thanks again Chris.

Black Color with Dark Roasted Head.  Bitter Roasted Coffee, Chocolate and Smoke on the Nose.  Promises to be a Beer of Some Magnitude.  Initially Thin Bodied but Increasingly Thick and Creamy.  Almost a Silkiness.  Subtle But Strong Notes...of Roasted Coffee, Prominence of Smoke and Some Dark Bitter Chocolate..Malts Still Keep This Brew From Being Too Bitter.  Peated Smoke and Bittering Aftertaste.  Well Balanced Smoke Beer. Hat is Tipped to Dark Horse for a Very Well Put Together Beer!
Bottle...dry stout with a decent roasted flavor, would have liked a bit more of the smoke-

Bottle from Silphium. Cool, roasty aroma, slightly lactic with a bit of fusels. Pours with almost no head. Has a bit of bite in the mouth, minerals, but is lightly roasted with a hint of maple-smoked bacon, a bit of lactic acid. Kind of makes you lick your lips. Pretty tasty, though little smoke to be found.

Opaque black pour. Fully diminishing brown head. Small remnants of lacing. Aroma is of nicely blended chocolate and roasted malts. This precedes a gentle but full wave of smoke. Cherries and light plums are also noted. Lighter smoke in the flavor, but still very present and well blended together. Light sugary berry sweetness follows, along with tart malts and caramel, and a touch of coffee and smoke on the back side. Finishes moderately bitter, from chocolate and a rambunctious dose of hops and ample roastiness. Palate is medium bodied and balanced.

Dark Horse sure does make a great stout.

Bottle.  Pours an inky jet black with no a small dark brown head.  A bit of smokiness, a lot of chocolate, roasted coffee notes on the nose.  The flavor is great.  Lots of coffee, chocolate, toffee, and a light smoky finish.  There is actually not a lot of smoke flavor to this beer, but it adds a great finish.  Maybe this is why I have never seen another smoked stout, it might be too strong a flavor to add smoke to.  The body is a tad light for a stout, but overall an excellent beer.  I like the smoke as a light finish on the beer as opposed to dominating the entire beer.

roasted coffee, nutty, woodsy aroma. beautiful black color with a nice espresso colored head.  smoked flavor is delicious but not overpowering and moves pleasantly from the front of the mouth to the back, although light on the palate it is still quite good.  i loved this series.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 12oz, thanks to ogglethorp for this. poured black with small tan head. nose has a nice mix of caramel, roast, chocolate, and smoke. flavor has a great dense chocolate, smoked ham and gouda, and caramel. mouthfeel is a tad thin and carbonation is low. i was surprised this was 8%. more of a stout than a smoked to me (needs more smoke!) but this is a tasty beer.

I have high expectations for this beer. i love smoke......i love stout.....i have loved all the other dark horse stouts.......so i should love this beer. just like the other stouts in this series it looks just like a stout should. thick black with a beautiful dark brown head. aroma heavy mocha ....creamy mocha nice stout aroma with a light funky hint of smoke. creamy balanced bittersweet mocha flavor with a hint of smoke. fantastic bittersweet smoked chocolate finish slightly acidic medium dry it almost has a meaty flavor. the finish is great. lightly smoked chocolate. just like the one and the too this is medium to full bodied with a nice silky smooth mouth feel. i would have given it a 5 with just a bit more weight. this beer didnt quite live up to my expectations but it is still fantastic. great subtle use of the smoke. not overbearing it just adds another layer to this beer. well done.

Got a good amount of chocolate and roasted malt in the aroma.Pours dark black with a medium tan head.Roasted malt really stands out in the flavor.Thin to medium mouthfeel with a smooth chocolate finish.

Black in color with thin, quickly dissipating head.  Aroma is of chocolate smoke.  The smoke aroma isnt strong and supports the roasted malt aromas.  Palate is creamy and makes this a pleasure to drink.  Subtle chocolate notes and mild smoky finish.  Smoky velvet to drink.

Thanks to brewblackhole for this bottle--a really great trader!  Light wood and smoked aroma comes form the black body with almost zero head.  Thin palate for a smoked.  Lightly roasted malt and just a hint of the smoked aspect.  Weak in most aspects, but still enjoyable.

No head at all - it looks like motor oil or liquid tar.  It sure is smokey in the aroma, as promised by the type of beer it claims to be, but theres no complexity here.  Some chocolate notes complimenting the smoke in the flavor - brown sugar and vanilla - a sweet, pleasant earthiness too. Its true, that smoked beers are not my favorites typically, but this is very nice nonetheless.  Chewy mouthfeel.  Pleasant, roasty finish.

12 oz bottle from Ughsmash (thanks, Jason!) - very viscous, opaque pour, with only a little light getting in around the edges of the top of the glass - no head to speak of - I hesitate to call the aroma smokey - its more like the roasted qualities of the stout are simply amplified - some dark fruit (black cherry, plum), port and black coffee in the aroma as well - the body is actually rather light, considering how thick the pour seemed - semi-sweet, with a bakers chocolate quality - moderate bitterness - some sweet stout flavors that are nearly overpowered by smoke, wood, tobacco and leather - it all comes together nicely near the end though, leaving a lingering dry, smokey flavor - I only wish this had more body to it.

12oz bottle, no date.  Pours a thick black with a ring of tan bubbles.  Aroma of roasty malts, charred wood, some coffee, figs and raisins--though not really sweet.  The char isnt as strong as it is in most smoked beers.  The smoky char comes through more in the flavor, as well as the addition of some molasses with an ashy chalky semidry finish.  Low bitterness seems to come from the roast.  Medium bodied with almost no carbonation at all.  Pretty good, but nothing phenomenal, either.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a jet black color w/ a light brown thin head that quickly dissapates and some decent lacing.  Big roasty malt aroma lots of coffees some light chocolates very dry not much smoke to the aroma although a little bit more comes out when the beer warms up.  Palate is nice, full bodied lightly creamy good coating.  Flavor is quite chocolaty some light roast coffees and a light lactose almost sour touch to it but not the kind of sour you associate with spoiling.  The smokiness comes through very lightly like drinking a chocolate stout near ribs on a bbq.  This is some great stuff probably the best smoked beer ive ever had.

Dark color.  Smell of roasted coffee, smoke, malt, caramel, berries, coco, and some hops.  Tastes the same but with caramel/toffee and a light sourness and bitter at the end.  Still a great stout!  Thanks Brewblackhole!

From a growler: Pours a flat black color with a medium thick and foamy brown head. Sticky patches of lacing. Strong and smoky roasted malt and coffee aroma. The body is rich and smooth and the smoky character is consistent but not overbearing. Roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee flavors mesh very well. The finish is dry and smoky with a fair amount of hops peeking through. Not really anything to complain about with this one.

Pours a thick and oily very dark brown-black, with a brief cap of tan foam that quickly turns into a sparse ring. A little foam clings to the sides of the glass after each sip, but then slides back into the beer in oily sheets. Amazing bold mocha java aroma, slightly smoky, slightly fruity, with lots of molasses. 

More bitter flavor than the aroma would indicate - heavier on the bitter coffee, bitter chocolate, and husky grain. No trace of the fruit or molasses from the aroma. Dry bitter woodsmoke and charred oak throughout. All of these plus hash oil in the aftertaste. 

Frickin hash oil of all things!

Mild carbonation, warming alcohol presence, but no alcohol flavors.
Bottle . Thansk to Styles. Poured a deep black like oil. Aroma of coffe and smoke is very present. The taste is of coffe and the smoke taste makes me think like I just bit into a smoked briskit.

Bottle courtesy of ford9719.  Heavy smells of oak, smoke, malt, and chocholate.  Creamy taste, with a strong smokey flavor, Pretty nice.  Pretty easy drinkin, a little light bodied for a stout, but okay.

Aroma was similar to Bamburg beechwood, totally dominated the aroma, no head(?), smooth mouthfeel(or was it flat) smokey malt and nut,with a coffee bean aftertaste,thin texture,almost a wateriness to it. Loved the smoke,but this needs more body

The beer gods smiled upon me when Willblake gifted this too me, thanks a lot Jon.  I have been shaving this till I could try it with my smoke loving buddy.  Fridged for 45 minutes. split into two small goblet glasses.  Pours opaque black, actually absorbs light.  No head and just a ghost of a brown lacing.  Aroma is strong on the peat smoke with present chocolate roastiness.  I mean this is a perfect smoked stout.  Has both characteristics present.  Taste is smokey with a sweet aftertaste.  Its actualy a pretty light beer, with alight mouthfeel.  A weird dicothmy. Low bitterness.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
Bottle.   Pour is nearly black, with 
small tan head that fades rather quickly.   Aroma coffee, malt, hint of smoke, burnt sugar.   Flavor is dark roasted malt, coffee, choclate, peat.   Palate is thick and full with a very roasty finish.   Dig it.

12 oz Bottle courtesy of Northerntimber.  What a nice surprise this was!  Such a nice roasty, malty aroma....and a great pour.  The taste is of coffee, malts, chocolate and a little bit of smoke.  Actually, I was afraid this was going to be too smokey, but its very light on the smoke.  Just a damn good stout...

12oz bottle via trade with styles! - Thanks! - Pours black and quite thick with a very small tan head that fades quick.. Aromas of coffee, light smoke, and some light chocolate as well.  Lots of roast there in the aroma as well. Flavor is roasty, smokey, and chocolate with coffee.  Some dark fruit there too.. Very chewy and thick palate with full body and very little carbonation.  Finish is all roast.. Good full flavored brew that was quite enjoyable..

Peaty aroma, soft smokiness as well, black, wearing a tiny cappuccino head. Flavour starts with strong coffee, bitter hops next with a fine liquorice taste at the finish. Full bodied, quite bitter. Fantastic!

Lots of roast coffee and bitter dark chocolate, not a whole lot of detectable smoke.  Aroma is mollasses, chocolate.  Thick, almost chunky palate.  A bit reminiscent of a chunky bar too, well if they made a dark chocolate version.  Thin to no tan head on opaque deep brown near black beer.  Hints of dark fruits.  There ise a very mild smokiness in the finish.  If you just think of it as a stout, its quite good.

Bottle. Dark motor oil consistency with a small ring of mocha head. The aroma is pleasant - very roasty chocolate, dry bitterness, chalky fruit, and the smoke is subdued. Interesting texture - quite smooth with significant chocolate roast and dry coffee. Finishes with toasty toffee flavour. I like it.

Thanks Styles!

12oz bottle acquired in trade with Styles (thanks!). Poured a dark, dark black (like pouring a can of oil) with an averaged sized brown head. Aromas of chocolate, roast, nuts, light coffee and light smoke. From the aroma, I wouldnt have guessed this was a smoked beer as the smoke was faint and in the background. Tastes of coffee, roast, light chocolate, and very faint smoke. Just like the aroma, the smoke is in the background and I had to reach deep to find it. Ends in a nice coffee bitter finish. Alcohol well hidden. Is this a great smoked beer - no. Is this a great beer - yes.

-Bottle. Quiet dark almost black, smallish head. Dried fruit, liquorish, wet brown leaf. Roast, malty, plenty of dark malt light chocolate noses, slightly bitter flavour. Good roast, a bit on dry side.

12 oz bottle, via Styles.  Completely black pour that swallows any light, under a thick dark chocolate pudding like head that settled to a creamy film.  Aroma is incredibly roasty and burnt, almost ashey.  Notes of chocolate, light alcohol, and chalk.  Flavor is just as roasty and burnt as the aroma suggests.  Just the lightest hint of smoke on the finish.  Very soft and well rounded flavor.  No noticable alcohol.  Mouthfeel is velvety and smooth with minimal to no carbonation.  Overall, this was pretty awesome.  These dudes can make a dark beer!  I will add my dissent to the categorization of this as a Smoked in addition to some of those before me.  Should be a Stout.

12oz bottle, another one of the ugliest labels on planet earth.  dark horse must pride themselves in attaining this feat.  they must try hard to make their labels so ugly, that I actually LIKE them!  so don;t change...  bottle courtesey of WillBlake, sharing the non-smoking tastes of Lou18 (more for me, thanks Lou!)  black body, short dark tan head that disapears to a ring quickly.  aroma is roasted malt and some dark chocolate.  smoke aroma is very light.  flavor is sweet chocolate malt, also roasted coffee.  a bit bitter in the finish.  a nice light-hearted stout, well worth the $1.67 price tag!  medium to thin body.  not that smoky.

Have drank this on many occasions, both at the brewery and out of the bottle at home. Out of the tap at the brewery I would rate this a 5. Pours very black and thick. Smoky roasted hops are evident beneath the heavy chocolate and coffee notes. A very complex, easy drinking stout.

12oz. bottle Black in color with a medium tan head. Mild roasted malt aroma with some coffee as well. Flavor was pretty much the same, but with a touch of smoke added in there as well. Smooth and easy drinking stout.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry courtesy of Silphium. Sixth beer of our Dark Horse Brewing tasting. Pours black with a small diminishing brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, mild smoke, a touch of chocolate and some coffee. Flavour of mild smoke, coffee, chocolate, some fruit and a mild hop finish. Medium to full bodied. This is very easy to drink and a very pleasant Stout. Im pretty impressed with Dark Horse tonight, theyve all been very good to excellent so far.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, his bottle.  Poured opaque black with a small dark brown head.  Nice, typical roast stout aroma - nutty, light coffee, slightly tart fruit notes - with some cola character, theres smoke here, but not much - not sweet, but not all that bitter either.  Tasted pretty much as it smelled, just more hop and tart fruit bitterness - average at most time spent on the tongue, and fairly minimal smoke character.  Mouthfeel quite smooth, lightly carbonated and astringent - simply just a nice classic stout (I really dont see why this counts as a "smoked" beer - the smoke is minimal)

Pours with a black body topped by a thin head with little lacing.  Its slightly sweet and roasty with a nice malt note and a little coffee and chocolate.  The flavor has an added smokiness.  Full bodied and smooth.

Thanks Cquiroga!  Pours a very thick black color with a small dark tan head and no lasting lacing.  Aroma is acidic and fruity with a slightly roasted note to it.  Flavor is super smoky like eating a mouthful of hickory chips.  Its very smooth and had a big mouthful.  Im not traditionally a big fan of smoked beers, but the combinatin of the smokiness and the palate feel really made this an enjoyable beer.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with Eyedrinkale, thanks Mike!) Been sitting on this one for almost a year, so its had some time to do its thing in the bottle.  Hardly a wimper when I pop the cap, and pouring the beer, whoa, this is black, black, black!  Looks like used motor oil, with a fairly thick viscosity.  The light brown head is about as dark a cap as Ive seen on a beer, but its extremely small, barely cover the beer with a full layer, and completely dissipates in under a minute.  But wow, its fully black even at the edges when held to a sunlight, so you cant get any darker and more opaque than this.  The piquant, intense nose projects a very earthy and roasty aroma, plenty of decaying wood, and strong hints of delicious, sweet, chocolate-coated cherries.  Not getting much in the way of smoke, however.  Some differences in the flavor though, with quite a bit more coffee showing up.  Its roasty and fairly bitter, earthy and mushroomy, only slightly sweet, plenty of that cherry and chocolate combination.  But again, smoke isnt really all that noticeable, and thats probably because the stout shows so much roastiness and ash that smoke wouldnt really add much.  Lightly carbonated, as one would assume given the nearly headless pour.  Full bodied, but not thick and heavy, so this makes it a pretty easy drinking beer for one that packs such rich and intense flavor.  Extremely flavorful enjoyable beer, one that drank pretty easy for me, and my now-empty glass provokes much sadness.

Thanks to Styles for this beer.  Poured black with ruby highlites and a dark brown fizzy head that dissipated quickly.  Light aroma of cherries, bitter coffee, some fruity acidity.  Taste is light roasted coffee, a bit of funk, some mild fruit essences.  Medium slick oily body.  Whatever smokiness that was intended to show in the flavor profile seems to be assimilated into the trademark roastiness of stout, and is thus not especially noteworthy.  However it is still a pretty nice stout.

The body is black with absolutely no light showing through. There is a very thin light yellowish and orange head. The aroma is smoked malt with some moss caramel and molasses. The taste is coffee and dark chocolate. There is also some bread crust and peanuts. This has a relatively thin body. Another winner from Dark Horse. Thanks for the sample, Duane.

last of the bottles acquired via trade with Walleye.  shared this one with Eric as part 2 of a mini tasting tonight.  Dark Horse has provided some excellent beers and this is no exception.  fairly strong smokey aroma and flavor, expecially up front.  But agter a couple of sips, this just smoothed out to a nice malty, smoked beer with a nice full palate.  poured a jet black with a slight ruby edge.  I was really digging this one!

from he bottle. poured balck wit a brown head that left no lacing. aroma dark fruits malts, chocolate, molasses, cherries, had to wait until it warmed up for the smoke to come out. flavor the smoke came out 1st than a sweet chocolate, malt, dark sweet berries as it warmed the flavors got a little more robust. not too bad of a beer.
Blackish pour with minimal head.  Aroma of smoke, backed by dark malts, roast,  bitter coffee, and ash.  Quite an interesting style, not something Id buy more than one of though.

A long life has treated this beer well, I had lots of it when it first came out last year, and I thought the flavors were much to sharp, and there was acidity from the roast malts that made it hard for me to drink.  It has mellow.  Opague black, no head.  Flavor is roasted, coffee and a little smoke.  Medium bodied stout, with a moderately dry finish.  Well made, I will have to acquire a few more of this and lay them down for awhile.

Deep black, motor oil pour.  Very little head, in fact rather flat.  Roasted aroma with slight smoke.  Lots of bitter chocolate, smoked malts and espresso coffee in the flavor.  Lingering firewood in the mouth.  Not too smokey, but a tasty beer.  Thanks Brad!

Pours jet black. The head consisted of a brown haze and a few little bubbles that stuck to the edge of the glass, needless to say it was mostly diminishing. No lacing to speak of. Aroma is a mix of coffee and the smell your clothes get after sitting around a campfire all night. Taste is initially burnt espresso and dark chocolate, hops make their presence known somewhere in the middle. Flavor is smokey throughout. This brew should only be drank at about 55 degrees F. The flavor improves immensely. The chocolate and coffee become more pronounced as the beer warms. Just enough sweetness comes though to balance the smoke and char. Finish is very long and leaves you with a bit of an  ashy aftertaste. This beer is full bodied, syrupy and mouth coating.

Thanks to Secret Santa Crosling for this one!  Oily black pour, deep brown head barely broke the surface before dying off.  Restrained roasty and smoked aroma.  Flavor was initially deep roast, followed by an unrelenting attack of ash and char.  Bizarre sensation of having a layer of soot left in my mouth after having swallowed.  Interesting though.  Smoked?  How about burnt?  As it warmed, the ashiness gave way a bit to a more traditional dark roast profile with a faint hint of espresso and perhaps even some fruitiness.  Medium body.  Not a bad beer, despite what this description sounds like.
This is my first smoked beer.  Thanks silphuim.  Pours dark black little brown head. smells of smoke and coffee.  smooth drinking thin bodied beer.
First smoked beer, not very strong smoke in there though, but a delicious stout!  Smoky, rich, bitter coffee.  Seemed rather thick, like a lighter imperial.  Go Dark Horse!

Pours dark black with wispy beige head. Aroma is all smoke and coffee. Flavor much the same with a long smoke aftertaste. A little thin/watery. Smoke is right next to coffee in my least favorite flavor. Sorry.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, fully diminishing. Body is black. Aroma is heavily malty (coffee, burnt grain, chocolate), lightly hoppy (resin), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with a note of smoke. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. Not bad, but not terribly exciting.
Very smoky aroma, opaque and very dark color. Smokiness remains in the flavor, joined by coffe and slight chocolate. Feels nice in the mouth. Good beer, not great.

Bottle. Pours viscous, oily with no head. Nice aroma of cocoa, chocolate and a little smoke. Taste is rich with chocolate and smoke malts. Great smokey taste, pretty unique in that the finish is a hearty, campfire smokiness. Oily mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Beyond opaque black color, with a small, filmy mocha colored head that quickly falls.   Aroma is pretty expressive, with a nice balanced of peaty scotchy hints and chocolate, cocoa, caramel and coffee aromas.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin and initially the flavor is completely lacking in both the front-palate and the mid-palate, until the finish yields rich scotch flavors, light smoke, chocolate, caramel, light malt bitterness and light sourness.  I enjoyed the different segments together, but not as a whole.  The mouthfeel is very thin, especially considering Dark Horses standards and the flavor, overall, isnt that enjoyable.

Thanks to mjames for sharing this one. Didnt look that impressive, as there was absolutely no head. While the aroma didnt knock you down like the Calumet smoked, it was very nice. Drank while eating some of mjames elk steak, it was a nice pair, and reminded me of a slightly sweet smoked pulled pork bbq. The only thing I didnt like was a really thin mouth feel, which both seemed to coat my mouth and disappear at the same time.

Pours perfectly opaque, viscous and oily. Head is dark brown and lazy. However, the small bit that does reside around the edges leaves gorgeous mahogany lacing when the liquid is swirled in the snifter.  Smell is rich, of chocolate cookies, smoky leather, and a distinct almond and cream that it is unique for a stout. Really a fine smelling beer, like being tucked deep in a leather smokers chair.  Mouthfeel is richly smooth and oh so smoked. Pork barbecue, chipotle peppers and cigarettes, is what its like, but they all contribute without being gimmicky. Elegantly they mesh with the roasted chocolate malts and rich pit fruits. Its a boldy packed palate and it works extremely well for such a full load. The guys out West with their massive stouts ought to take notes.  Aftertaste is chocolate, fruit and some alcohol  strong, but unobtrusive. Cheers to my great friend jgb9348 for bringing this back to me from Michigan as part of my college graduation gift!

Aroma:  plastic, musty basement, coco, some smokiness, some red grapes, cream, and sugar

Appearance:  dark brown-->black, tan head, some lacing

Flavor:  semi-sweet chocolate, coco, smokiness, and some cream

Palate:  very smooth, slight chalky coco aftertaste

Pitch black with no head.  Looks flat.  Smoky and sweet, but not as smoky as expected, very mild compared to other smoked stouts tasted (Bieropholie, OFallon).  Some nice dark chocolate, very good overall, with a slightly smoky finish and a somewhat watery thin and oily palate.  Caramel and scotch aromas noticed at warmer temperatures.
Bottle. Dark brown with a tan head. Roasted malts all over the nose. Mouth is velvety, thick and tasty.

04.13.05  12oz bottle trade thanks to jtw.  Totally black pour, one of the blackest and thickest Ive seen; thin brown head.  Hibachi smoke aromas, charred stuff on the grill, a touch lactic, roasty, not very complex.  Full, unctuous, bitter palate.  Nice astringency to finish.  Smoke does not carry much into flavor and its jsut a very good, very roasty, very bitter stout.  Hopped up and potent.

Bottle... Pitch black with a very small, fizzy, light brown head... gone in a flash. Prune, tobacco, light smoke, dark cherries and dark raisins in the aroma. The well-balanced flavor is chocolatey and smokey with blasts of molasses, toffee and dark fruit. Rich, full-bodied and oily with light carbonation. Lengthy, roasted, blackstrap finish with mild bitterness and silky, chocolatey sweetness. Dark horse does stouts right. Thanks go out to eyedrinkale for providing me with the bottle!

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2006 Rerate on 5/6/06 after being cellared for a year:  Pours a very rich, dark opaque with a nice, thin brownish head.  Has an earthy, grainy toasted cereal aroma with some light smoke and sweet milk chocolate.  Body starts with a nice, lightly sweet dark caramel flavor balanced with some drier, earthy smoke and lingering roasted malts and dark chocolate.  A very tasty smoked stout. This really reminds me of Stone 6th Anniversary Porter when it was fresher.

Sampled at the 3/25/05 Tosa Gathering, courtesy of JPDIPSO: Pours a viscous oily, nearly opaque with a thin whispy tan head.  Has a rich, sweet, roasty, and well-smoked aroma.  Starts rich and bready with nice sweet, yet dry smokiness, and a touch of butterscotch toward a smooth, dark chocolatey finish.  Nice complexity and well-balanced.  Very enjoyable, thanks John!

Bottle pours black, quite opaque, medium dark brown foamy head, with nice brewers lace. &nbsp Certainly looks inviting. &nbsp Smoked wood, campfire of sorts, on the nose. &nbsp Perhaps a slight hint of roasted malts and maybe even some coffee. &nbsp Smokey lactose like sweetness up front. &nbsp The stout portion is quite soft, and very nice. &nbsp The smokiness of this beer isnt in charge, but blends well with the burnt/roasted malts. &nbsp Body & mouthfeel are medium to full. &nbsp Finishes with lingering lactose like sweetness on a bed of smoked wood. &nbsp Soft and subtle... very nice indeed. &nbsp Thanks goes out to jtw for the trade!!

Very dark pour, no head... just a small ring around glass. The beer leaves a nice oily stain on the glass. Rich roasted chocolate aroma with bourbon soaked burnt wood. Flavor has a rich charcoal smoked chocolate taste, along with some nuts. Good stuff... very filling!

Pours a dark brown color, small white head. Aroma of campfire, and burning/smoked moss. A little chocolate as well. Flavor is smoked and roasted chocolate and caramel, with more campfire to it. Thanks to JpDipso for this one.

Sure as hell smells smoky with a rich malty essence.  Thick, black and impenetrable in appearance.  Nice, full, smoky taste.  Cocoa and espresso laden.  Heavy, smoky tactile feel that dominates the palate with a strong molasses presence.  Rich and lively.  Damn right.

Had this at the Tosa tasting.  Aroma: Spiced meat.  Pepperoni, beef jerky.  Smoky.  Appearance: Dark black, dark tan head, head ring, decent lacing.  Flavor: Typical stout with smoke flavoring, cocoa, bitter.  Palate: Acedic.  Full body.
this was a great beer!  black body with small medium brown head.  Wonderful smoked, chocolately smell...flavor is of smoke, strong in chocolate, and a touch of tartness to it....great palate
got this from John. All I can say, I was warned, I do not like smoke brew. Oh,  I  really do not. It reminds me of the time my wifes families house burnt down. Bad .

Motor oil black, ultra dark tan creamy head.  If you dont like smoke beers, stay away and leave them to me!  Heavy hitting aromas of smokey bacon and burnt wood, with perfect underlying notes of mocchachino and dark bitter-sweet chocolate.  The taste off the bat was campfire like, Turkish coffee in the middle, followed up with a nice dosage of bittering hops to round this out.  Medium bodied, pillow soft carbonation, drying bitter smoked finish.  If its your thing.....find some now!  Awesome.....

Near black with a smaller silk brown head. Dark molasses mingles with fresh cut oak and peat. This would go well with a bavarian marinated steak. Fairly thin, but silky in feel  Glides nicely from start to finish. Roasted malt with only a light peat influence. Seems to need a touch more of both in my book. I can see this being a starter smoked brew. Has a mild peat and dry nut linger. Still my other bottle will go well with my next steak. Thanks Lou. Ill likely enjoy the next one more, since I wont be thinking out it as much.
Black color with a dark brown head. Nice roasty coffee and chocolate aroma. Slightly sweet and smokey chocolate, coffee, and plum flavors. Slightly dry finish.

Pitch black color with a small brown head. The aroma and flavor were delightfully smoky (although not nearly as smoky as the traditional German smoked beers,) a little bit of tart chocolate, roasty coffee, and a sweet fruity (plum?) character. The feel was very crisp on the tongue...semi-dry finish. Thanks Wohlfs!

Pitch black oily pour. Dark tan, brown really, head. Beautiful brown lacing all over the glass. The aroma is smoke, peat, chococlate, and some espresso. The flavor is nice and meaty. Interesting presentation of the sweet malts, meaty smoke, and roasted bitterness. Very interesting and quite good. Full creamy body, dry roasty finish. I thought that a sweetmeat was a pastry or a piece of candy, this beer is sweetmeat. Yum. Thanks to wohlfs for the bottle!

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2005 Bottle. Im kind of surprised no other brewer I know of has done a smoked stout. Oily black with a nice tan head that laces. You can smell the smoke from an arms length. Taste is nice & burnt caramel and malts. Silky smooth flavors of chocolate and ash. Fantastic.

Bottle bought at Tiffanys in Kalamazoo.  Pours dark black, small dark brown head.  Not much aroma, slight smoked/burnt hardwood with a hint of cocoa.  Slightly sweet taste before the smoked malts and hops take over.  Good hop balance for the style, finishes with a bitter woodsy flavor.  Not as smoked as Id hoped when I saw the color, not a bad brew.

Bottle. Thanks to wohlfs for the trade. Pours  thick and black with a small dark brown head.  Nose is light coffee, roasted malt, burnt wood, and dark, bittersweet chocolate. Taste is much sweeter than expected. More dark, bittersweet chcolate with light smokiness, coffee and roasted malts. Faint wood as well. Very creamy mouthfeel along with mild bitterness. Gets dry towards the end. Finish is a bit more smoke, roasted malt, chocolate and light coffee. Very good beer!

bottle-pours a pitch black hue that was very oily during the pour.  Looks very similar to the cream stout.  This beer is topped with an awesome chocolate brown head.  aroma of coca, roast, coffee, but where is the smoke?  Flavors are very similar to the aroma, which is a good thing.  The smoke shows up a little on the finish, but it is never in the forefront.  The beer has a long burnt finish with hints of that smoke, but very subtle.  Awesome palate once again.  Lots of black patent malt in this one.  Another winner from this fine brewery.  This could be the least-known brewery on ratebeer and also the most under-rated.  Does Michigan make a bad stout?  Thanks again Woflhs!

Bottle:  Very nice roasted coffee, chocolate, and light smoke.  Pours a dark brown, virtually black, with light brown head that lasts a minute or so.  Malty up front with a roasted coffee and decent smoke finish.  All the smoke flavor is in the finish.   Moderate cafe mocha aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2005 deep thick black color, with little carbonation.  lots of deep burnt woody aromas, lots of roasty dark malts too.  has a gritty mouthfeel somehow, although it drinks very smoothly.  more smoke in the end.  pretty good, very interesting to say the least.

Bottle couretesy of Marinaro500.  Opaque black as the others in this series.  Little head and carbonation, just like the others.  Body is medium to full.  Aroma is deeply roasted grains and just a hint of the smoked malt.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Roasted/burnt grain and slight smoke towards the finish.  Damn nice stout in their lineup of good stouts!  Now if they would just release the Imperial!!!!!

An interesting batch of stouts being offered from Dark Horse, and this one is no different.  Similiar to the "Too," this one pours a very dark color.  More hints of chocolate, coffee -- espresso roasted -- and earth.  A lot of the smoke flavors didnt come through, and I wished they did.  Nice consistency.

Completely opaque black. Thick mocha head fringes the broken layer. Evenly displayed aroma of assorted berries, ink, soil, and rich espresso. Feeble smoke, prunes, charcoal, leafy hops, and phenols. Thick, oily body. Velvety enough. Bready, ink-drizzled malts soften the moderate acidity. Other than adding some grit to the body, smoke is hardly a factor. Tar and burnt malts inundate the palate but are held in check by the dark berry bedding. Sufficient vanilla, caramel, and a sprucey hop undertow soften the body and smoothen the delicious black malt astringency. Soft roast intermingles with the prune acidity and harsh earthy malt elements. Finishes dry, chalky, and burnt with suggestions of ink, rich espresso, bittersweet chocolate, and their signature black malt stamp. Perpetual burnt malt and vanilla remnants. Yet another DH beer with spectacular execution of roast and char integration. If theyd somehow do away with that yogurty acidity, which seemingly underlies every one of their stouts and detracts from the body and overall richness, and add more rauch malt to this one in particular, theyd have some true humdingers. Youve gotta love how every stout of theirs is pitch black and darker than most Imperials.  Nice!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
UPDATED: OCT 27, 2004 These guys make the most beautiful beers in the world!!!  It is a work of art, just dark enough that light doesnt penetrate, with just a touch of red in there, billowy head that sticks relentlessly to the sides of the glass...
Nose was a bit peaty and chocolatey, but that didnt come out too strong in the taste.  Mostly just creamy coffee, some wateryness with a nice dry finish.  Not as good as it looks, but certainly worth the drive to Marshall! Thanks to Hopsrus.  UPDATE!  This beer is much tastier on tap, also, it is advised to keep the beer cold.  thicker, richer body, great aftertaste of roasted coffee and dry hops!

What is going on with this label? It looks like something that an abused elementary school student would draw during therapy, black hole appearance with a thin tan ring on the outskirts of town, a little light in the mouth, sweet flavor, a little woody, a little smokey, some hints of vanilla and bubble gum, not very carbonated, dry finish, and once again... worst label ever.
Very dark brown, it has some smokey aroma and flavors, but they dont overwhelm you. This is a slightly sweet stout w/ a nice tongue feel. I liked it. Thx hopsrus

Bottle:Ok nose little cream and smoke. Good reddish black color. No head. Roast grains, bakers chocolate, ash, smoke in the flavor. Thinner bodoed, creamy, drier finish. Tasty, seemed a little warming. Wasnt bad but didnt make me scream for another.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Extremely dark brown, honest tan head. Very mild smoke in the aroma. The beer base is not all about roastiness though, theres a nice roasted malt aspect which create cigarette and ashes flavors together with coffee and licorice malt profile. Lots of licorice on the tongue, coffee, lingering smoked chocolate... Medium bodied, light carbonation. Good beer with some typical dark horse quality marks, but this wont impress anyone and Id have loved more smoke... a lot more. Thanks psychprof.
Dry smoke and treacley over this all-malt lake...Rich consistency and roasty constituents galore develop into a dark chocolate bitterness...A few clouds signalling inherited tranquility...

Bottle. Small sized creamy and smooth light brown head and fine-medium sized bubbles that fully diminished. Uncarbonated, opaque and a black hue. Malty, coffee, burnt and roasty aroma. Malty and coffee taste with a thin mouthfeel. Sparse lacing.

This bottled brew from the brewery poured a small head of fine to medium sized dark brown colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a very good lacing.  The body was opaque black with no visible carbonation.  The aroma contained notes of smoky roasted dark malts coffee and mild chocolate.  The mouth feel was very smooth with a lingering coffee dark malt finish.  The brews flavor contained notes of dark malts coffee chocolate roasted malts and smokiness.  Very nice and well recommended.

Deep brown with ruby highlights that produced a large creamy tan head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of burnt dark malts, coffee, toffee, hazelnut, floral and grassy hops, and an earthy yeast ester. The taste is malty at the beginning with a fruity twang following. Additional undertones of mocha and nuts lingering around the palate. The finish has bitter notes from the hops, coffee, and smoke. The mouthfeel is lively and thin, chalky, the weakest part of the brew. Overall, its a solid entry into the style, but I like Dark Horse Black Bier slightly better.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2004 2004 bottle.  Pours opaque black, with deep orange-brown tinges on the sides and a small, but amazingly burnt-tan head.  Aroma is bitter and very much full of dry smoke.  Like hickory bbq, though not sweet.  Flavor is full of bitterness and smoke, though the smoke flavor is well-balanced and shares center-stage with the roast and hops.  Definitely a touch of bitter hops at the start followed by a pleasing roasted barley flavor.  Smoke really shows through towards the finish and there is a nice interplay of bitter floral hops with the smoke.  Bottle conditioned, medium body and quite smooth for the bitterness.  Dosent overdo it and is very drinkable.

Black, big foamy cocoa head.  Nose is smoked with light roasted coffee notes and a freshness that can only be called fruity.  Body is extremely smooth, hints of light smoke and a touch of chocolate at the front.  A bittersweet middle is accented by light bitter citrus hop notes.  Finished lightly bitter and smooth.  I could handle a bit more smoke and a bunch more roast, but a well balanced smokey stout.
smoky chocolate aroma, small thin head, sausagey smokiness then sweetness and finally like biting into a coffee bean, a nice array of flavors but not quite sure if they work together

Coffee, chocolate, highly smoked in the nose.  Black with a brown head thats tiny.   Big chocolate up front with lots of roast and coffee.   Intesely smokey but balanced by all the roast, coffee and chocolate.  I really enjoy this.

Poured a crude oil like black with a medium sized deep dark brown head.  smoky roasted malt aroma. taste is of charcoaled malt, with some chocolate and roasted coffee notes, leading to a slightly bitter finish. mouthfeel  was suprisingly a bit on the thin side, given that this poured like syrup, but didn't really detract from the enjoyment of this fine brew.
Dark, thick and smoked beyond doubt. This burnt roasted beverage has an interesting wang like its been marinated in "liquid smoke". Head is substantial. Certainly not lacking in flavor.

Pours like molasses or petroleum with a brown head.  Aroma is roasted malts, and the flavor is likewise heavy on roasted, burnt, smoked notes, with a hint of sweetness.  The body was a bit on the thin side.  The brewer's other stouts (and Black Bier porter) have the same smoked flavor as this beer does.

This is the first smoked ale beer that I can truly appreciate.  This poured with the darkest head I have ever seen.  The aroma is dominated by its smoked tones, smells like malt sweetness intermingled with clothes worn around a campfire.  The flavor begins like a normal stout, roasted, bitter, but it ends with a smoked twang.  This is a remarkably balanced beer and well worth trying.  Excellent paired with grilled salmon.
Poured a jet black with a small dark brown head.A smoky malt aroma. Roasted coffee, chocolate and black malt taste. A nice hop bitterness and a slighty smokey flavor. An impressive brew.

Opaque with a thick, foamy, burnt powdered cocoa head. Slowly streaming carbonation. Burnt coffee, burnt chocolate and burnt black malt aroma with hints of dry barley. Soft, thick and lightly fizzy. Not smoked at all, but merely charred with loads of seared malt flavors and a bittersweet cocoa and coffee aftertaste. Very silky feel to it as it sits. Medium full body. Carbonation lessens. Long, brooding dark malts linger with an emphatic black malt harshness. Turns a little oily late with an emerging hop bitterness and burps. Finishes with a dominating black malt astringency and some hints of oat smoothness. Fairly high alcohol it seems as well. Very good.

Pours a thick jet black color, small bubbly brown head, smokey roasty malt aroma. Sweet burnt flavors, slight smoke flavor in the mix, full creamy mouthfeel that explodes with roasted goodness, I love it, thanks PsychProf for another great one from this brewery.

Ridiculously dark in color, with a wee dark head. Aroma is initially roasted malts and some hops, but shifts to whiffs of meaty smokiness.  Malt flavor as well starts with chocolate/roast maltiness, and then a waave of smoke hijacks the malt flavor and finishes quickly.  Smoke flavor is most pronounced initially, then goes away until almost the end, when is pops its head to sour the last 4 ounces.  The first 8 ounces of this beer were way more enjoyable than the last fore.  Sorry, awful pun.  Pretty interesting and the rating would end up higher if I could erase the last 3 or 4 sips from my memory.  Thanks to Psychprof for the surprise!

The fourth in the Dark Horse stout series - are these guys raising a flame to rival the folks in Kalamazoo?  In any event, I liked this stout and appreciated the subtleties of its smoked nature - definitely present in the aroma,  the smoke slipped elusively through various cracks left by the decent roasts and herbality in the flavour.   When I finally caught up with the little guy he proteus-shifted on me until I couldnt tell if it was good clean oakfire smoke or just the interesting edges of roasted barley I was getting.  I like the way you get a breif, creamier sensation in the mouth before the harder smoky and roasty edges set to work ... oh, and Michael, Im down with that impressive brown head note - Im a sucker for dark heads on stouts and this one was the darkest of my experience.

Another solid effort from this Marshall, MI, brewery. Not as heavily smoked as other smoked beers I have had. A wonderfully dark brown head rises on this woodsy, hoppy, smoked malt brew. Medium-bodied. Would be a good introduction to smoked beers for someone who likes dark beers but is otherwise smoke-naive (kind of like me!).
